With the growing expenses of her family as her children grow older, Flor wants to improve her family's economic status by growing her business and no longer borrowing money from usurious money lenders who charge huge interest rates. She felt very lucky that she was able to join ASHI and had the opportunity to request a loan that has the smallest interest rate. With the loans she is requesting now and can request in the next months or years, the life of her family will improve and her dream ensuring that her children graduate from college will be achieved.

loans.use: To purchase seedlings and fertilizers, and to rent tractors and other farming equipment for rice planting

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia G., 61, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She makes sure that she earns enough so that her family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store and operating a water station, which supplies her neighboring community with fresh drinking water. She also manages a community preschool, which caters to the children of the community.

Alicia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses, which helps her to consistently pay her dues.     

To ensure the success of her businesses, she would like to apply for a PHP 50,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding businesses. Alicia will buy replenishment stock for her variety store and other needs for her other businesses.

She dreams that her businesses will continue to grow so that she can provide for her grandchildren’s education.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy replenishment stock for her variety store and other needs for her other businesses

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
Lanie F., 39, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Allan F., a seaman, they are blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling cold cuts of meat for quite some time now.

Lanie has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 9,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more quantities of her usual products to be incorporated into her current stock inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her childrens' education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: Towards buying more quantities of her usual products to be incorporated into her current stock inventory.

loans.name: Nema

texts.en:
Because of low educational attainment due to low economic status, Nema M. and her husband were not able to get good-paying jobs. Therefore, they were not able to support the needs of their three children, especially the financial need to sustain their education until college. Therefore, the same thing happened to their children: they are now 22 to 26 years old and are working as laborers. Nema’s eldest and youngest children are fishermen while her middle and only daughter works as a housemaid. As a mother, Nema felt sad for the lack of achievement by her children. However, despite the hard work her children do every day, they are still happy and are enjoying their lives with their parents.

When Nema joined ASHI in 2006, she and her family were very happy. With the opportunity to receive a loan, their family can have a business that everybody can work in and have earnings from. Since Nema’s two sons are into fishing, Nema decide to support them financially by using the loan from ASHI to make their business grow and become profitable. Now, Nema is requesting for a much larger loan because she wants to purchase a motorboat for her sons to manage. She is the one who sells their fish to people in their village and in the market.

Nema hope that one day their business will be profitable and sustainable enough for her only daughter to work with her in trading their fish instead of working as a housemaid, for which she receives only a very small salary.

loans.use: To purchase a motorboat for fishing.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia C., 35, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Michael C., a Government Transportation Employee, they are blessed with five children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own ready-to-wear clothing stall for quite some time now.

Amelia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now, attending their weekly fellowship meetings and paying her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. Amelia is consistent in paying her dues because she has used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her clothing business.

To ensure the continued success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan as a source of added capital to her expanding business to allow her to buy more quantities of clothing to replenish her stock and continue operations of the clothing stall. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can afford to have branches of her store in malls.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of clothing for her clothing stall

loans.name: Sharifan's Group

texts.en:
Sharifan is 28-years old, married, and has five children. She lives in a mid-size city named Riwind, in Pakistan. Riwind city is famous for its dairy business. 
Sharifan is a very friendly-natured woman. She always tries to spread happiness to people. She is also a very vigorous lady. She runs her embroidered clothes selling business. She purchases the clothes from different cities (Multan and Faisalabad) because of their cheap rates and good quality. Her selling is limited to her neighbors. Her children are getting an education from the local school and she wants to give them a good education because she believes that education is a vital key to a person's success. 

Sharifan's husband's name is G. M.. He runs a grocery shop in the community. He has been running this shop for the past 3 years. They both earn well from their businesses and manage the financial expenses. She has successfully repaid her three loans to Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan for the fourth time to purchase groceries for her husband's grocery shop.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for a grocery shop.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda C. is from the village of Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Rosalinda is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns & operates a business venture making and selling "chicharon" (fried pork rinds) in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosalinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the third loan taken out by Rosalinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Aytolkun Malikova`s Group

texts.ru:
Маликовой Айтолкун 33 года. Она замужем, и мать 2 детей. Ее супруг работает таксистом в Ноокате, сама же занимается торговлей овощей и фруктов на центральном рынке города Ноокат. Бизнес был начат 5 лет назад с торговли картофеля. Данный кредит будет использован для увеличения товарного запаса овощей и фруктов. Ежемесячный доход от бизнеса составляет около 150 долларов. 

Назгул, 23, замужем. Ее супруг работает в электрической компании. Она проживает вместе с семьей супруга. Назгул работает в паспортном столе. Кредит будет использован для закупа МРС для дальнейшего откорма.

Мурату 26 лет. Он женат, его супруга работает учительницей в сельской школе. Семья клиента занимается животноводством и кредит будет использован для закупа КРС. В будущем клиент планирует существенно увеличить поголовье домашнего скота.

Рысгул 68 лет. Она вдова и мать 7 детей. В основном ее дети работают в РФ, ежемесячно отправляют деньги своей матери. Кроме этого она вместе с младшим сыном занимется сельским хозяйством, а именно выращиванием картофеля. кредит нужен для закупа минеральных удобрений.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Aytolkun M. is 33 years old. She is married and the mother of two children. Her husband is a taxi driver in Nookat, and she sells fruits and vegetables at the Noogat central market. Her business was launched five years ago when she started selling potatoes. The loan will be used to increase her fruits and vegetables stock. Her monthly income is about 150 US dollars. Nazgul, 23 years old, is married. Her husband works for an electric company. She lives together with her husband’s relatives. She works in the registry office. The loan will be used to purchase small cattle for fattening and resale. Murat is 26 years old. He is married, and his wife is a teacher in a village school. The family also raises animals and the loan will be used to purchase more cattle. In the future he plans a substantial increase of livestock. Rysgul is 68 years old. She is a widow and the mother of seven children. Her children mostly work in the Russian Federation, sending her some money every month. In addition, together wither youngest son, she does farming, more specifically growing potatoes. The credit is needed to purchase mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables and fruits

loans.name: Nasira's Group

texts.en:
Nasira is a wife of S. A. and they both live in a mid-size city named Riwind, in Pakistan. Riwind city is famous for its dairy business. 
She is a 49-year old woman. She owns a two room brick house, which she made three years ago with the earnings of her husband and from her embroidered clothes business. This was their big achievement and they feel proud of themselves. 
They have six children: three sons and three daughters. Their elder daughter is married and the next two help Nasira in her embroidery business. Their sons help their father in his loading business. Currently, they have a donkey cart which they used to load items, such as cements and bricks, and then deliver it to the required place. 

Nasira has successfully repaid her three loans to Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to purchase another donkey cart for her elder son so he also becomes helpful and meet the financial expenses.

loans.use: To purchase another donkey cart for loading.

loans.name: Adelfa

texts.en:
Adelfa C. is from the village of Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Adelfa is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Adelfa owns & operates a business venture  preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Adelfa is just starting this business.

In 2006, Adelfa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Adelfa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Adelfa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used for additional capital for her business. This will be the second loan taken out by Adelfa from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy L. is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Already a widow at 53, she is blessed to have her three children. She makes sure that she earns so that her family can have a better life. She has been managing her variety store, while also maintaining a piggery, for quite some time now.

Nancy has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business. She will be buying more quantities of products to be incorporated into her current stock inventory. She also will invest some of the loan to maintain their pigs.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: Towards buying more quantities of products to be incorporated into her current stock inventory. She also will invest some of the loan to maintain their pigs.

loans.name: Delm

texts.en:
Delma G., age 55, is from the village of Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is unmarried. To make a living, Delma makes a living by buying and selling fish in the local community. Delma has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Delma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Delma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fish to sell. Delma is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to gain additional capital for her business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Delma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Ma. Dely

texts.en:
Ma. Dely A., 41, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Sonny A., a driver/mechanic, they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been selling frozen foods while also maintaining a cosmetics and underclothing direct selling line.

Ma. Dely has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 24,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business. She will buy more quantities of the usual products in her current product inventory to replenish stocks and to maintain operations of her businesses.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She envisions herself to be God’s worker, and she hopes that, through her businesses, she can help as many people as she can.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: Towards buying more quantities of the usual products in her current product inventory to replenish stocks and maintain operations of her businesses

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth Pejere, 47, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Arsenio, a seaman, they are blessed with five children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store while also selling different varieties of vegetables, meat and seafood.

Lilibeth has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues. She uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 13,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business. She will be buying more quantities of the products in her current product inventory so that she can replenish her stocks and maintain operations of her businesses.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: Towards buying more quantities of the products in her current product inventory so that she can replenish her stocks and maintain operations of her businesses

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace D. G., 27, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Mel, an exhibitor, they are blessed with a child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own buy and sell business for quite some time now and she mostly sells accessories.

Grace has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 14,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more quantities of products that will be incorporated to her current inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: Towards buying more quantities of products that will be incorporated to her current inventory

loans.name: Lomotos

texts.en:
Lomotos V. is from the village of Banigan, liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 40 years old. Lomotos is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Lomotos owns & operates a business raising pigs for sale. Lomotos has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lomotos joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Lomotos has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Lomotos is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used again to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lomotos from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Cadelenia

texts.en:
Cadelenia J. is from the village of Antonino, Labason, Zamboanga Del Norte. She is 19 years old. Cadelenia is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Cadelenia owns & operates a business raising pigs for sale. Cadelenia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cadelenia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cadelenia is requesting a new loan of 2500 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Cadelenia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Nasirova Burma`s Group

texts.ru:
Бурма 36 лет. Она замужем и мать 2 детей. Дочь учится в школе, а сын ребенок дошкольного возраста. Она вместе с супругом имеют собственный цех по переработке лесоматериалов. Раньше супруг работал в подмастерьях, но со временем накопил деньги и открыл свой собственный бизнес. Кредит необходим для закупа шифера для кровли собственного дома.

Омуркан, 28, замужем. Она замужем во втором браке, и у нее двое девочек от первого брака. Старшая дочь школьница. Супруг работает строителем. Кредит нужен для ремонта дома.

Мурзаим 48 лет. Она вдова и мать 4 детей: 3 сына и одна дочь. Старший сын находится на заработках в России, дочь замужем, по хозяйству помогают двое младших сыновей. Клиент занимается пошивом национальных изделий.  Кредит нужен для закупа материалов для шитькая. 

Кайра 53 года. Она тоже вдова. У нее двое сыновей. Клиент вместе со старшим сыном занимается откормом и перепродажей скота. Бизнес был начат с покупки одной коровы, в данное время у нее есть корова с теленком, два барана и 4 ягненка. кредит запрашивается для закупа КРС.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Burma, 36 is married mother of two children--a school-age daughter and a son of pre-school age. Burma and her husband own a timber processing plant. In the past, Burma's husband worked as a helper, but gradually he saved enough money to open his own business. This loan will be used to purchase roofing materials for Burma's family home. Omurkan, 28 is married for the second time. She has two daughters from her first marriage. Her older daughter is a school student. Omurkan's husband is a construction worker. This loan will be used to repair the family's house. Murzaim, 48 is a widow and a mother of four: three sons and one daughter. Murzaim's oldest son is a migrant worker in Russia. Her daughter is married and the two youngest children help Murzaim around the house. Murzaim tailors folk clothing and and will use this loan to purchase fabrics and other sewing materials. Kayry, 53 is a widow and a mother of two. Together with her older son, Kayry maintains a cattle farm. She started the business with a single cow and has grown to contain a cow, a calf, two rams, and four lambs. This loan will be used to purchase animal food for the farm.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy building materials and business supplies

loans.name: Kaniz's Group

texts.en:
Kaniz lives in the mid-sized city of Riwind in Pakistan. Riwind is famous for its dairy business. Kaniz is a seamstress and has been in this profession for the last five years. She is an expert in her profession and can stitch designer and non-designer clothes easily. She receives orders from her neighbors and relatives. She has set charges for the stitching and charges Pak Rs. 100 for simple dresses and Pak Rs. 150 for designer clothes. Her earnings allow her to pay the family's utility expenses. 

Her husband, A. R., is a motor mechanic and runs a motor workshop in the main market. He has eight years of experience in this profession and can repair all types of vehicles. 

Kaniz is a regular client of Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. She has successfully repaid three loans to Asasah and now is applying again for a loan to purchase the repairing tools for her husband’s motor workshop.

loans.use: To purchase repair tools for the motor workshop

loans.name: Kutmidinova Baktygul`s Group

texts.ru:
Бактыгул 33 года. Она замужем и мать 4 детей. Старшие дети учатся в школе. Ее супруг работает строителем-плотником. Она помогает ему в цехе и производят домашнюю мебель. У них есть своя постоянная клиентура. Клиент собирается купить КРС для откорма и разведения и таким образом получить дополнительный источник дохода.

Шахзада, 50, замужем. У нее 7 детей: 4 дочери и 3 сына. Вся семья занимается земледелием. Они выращивают технические культуры. Кредит нужен для закупа минеральных удобрений.

Бурмакан 43 года. У нее 6 детей. Супруг клиента занимается частным извозом по району. Клиент дома имеет свое маленькое хозяйство и планирует купить еще одну корову, чтобы получать молоко и производить молочные продукты. 

Галбай, 39, женат. является единственным мужчиной в данной группе. Он оказывает услуги мельницы. На полученную прибыль от заработков в Казахстане купили китайскую мельницу и стабильно обслуживают население по помолу муки. Кредит запрашивается для закупа минеральных удобрений для использования при посеве картофеля.


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Baktygul, 33, is married and has 4 children. The older children attend school. Baktygul's husband is a construction worker/carpenter. Baktygul and her husband work together in a woodwork workshop making furniture. The business has earned loyal customers. Baktygul will use this loan to purchase cattle to start a cattle farm providing an additional source of income. Shahzada, 50, is married and has 7 children: 4 daughters and 3 sons. The whole family is farming land where they grow technical crops (such crops include cotton, sugar beets, sunflowers, etc.). This loan will be used to purchase mineral fertilizers. Burmakan, 43, has 6 children. Her husband has a private livery service. Burmakan has a small cattle farm and plans to purchase a cow to produce milk and dairy products. Galbay, 39, is the only male in this group of entrepreneurs. Galbay purchased a Chinese-made mill with the money he earned in Kazakhstan. He now provides reliable milling services to the local grain farmers. Galbay will use this loan to purchase mineral fertilizer to grow potatoes.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cattle and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy Bautista enjoys her life as a wife, mother, and business woman. She has two children, whose ages range from one to five years old. Her husband is a hired company driver. Despite having a hard time sustaining her business buying and selling rice, Juvy feels happy to be helping her husband support the needs of their family, especially their children.

Juvy wants to grow her business until it becomes profitable and a stable source of income to support the education of her children until they graduate from college. This vision inspires her to investing in growing her business through a loan from ASHI. Her husband is happier because of the productivity of his wife.

loans.use: To purchase large volume of rice for selling.

loans.name: Bermet Anasheva`s Group

texts.ru:
Бактыгул 40 лет. Она замужем и мать 3 детей. Старшая дочь находится в России на заработках. Клиент вместе с супругом проживают в городе и работаю в войсковой части. Дома имеются живности, при откорме которых помогают родственники проживающие в селе. Кредит запрашивается для закупа 2 телят для увеличений поголовья скота. 

Бурма, 29, замужем. ее супруг работает строителем, плотником и каменьщиком. У нее двое дочерей дошкольного возраста. Семья клиента занимается земледелием, в этом году собираются посеять картофель. Кредит запрашивается для закупа семян. 

Алтынбеку 35 лет. Его супруга домохозяйка и воспитывает двух детей. Сам же работает частным строителем-плотником, работает по заказу. По окончании службы в армии работал подмастерьем с наставником. На кредиту он планирует купить живность для откорма и перепродажи. 

Бермет, 33, замужем. Ее супруг также работает частным строителем. Клиент занимается земледелием. Кредит будет погашаться также за счет дохода супруга. Цель кредита - купля семена и минеральных удобрений. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Baktygul, 40, is married mother of of three. Her oldest daughter is a migrant worker in Russia. Baktygul and her husband live in a city and work at a military base. They have a small cattle farm at home. Baktygul's relatives, who live in a village, help with feeding the animals. This loan will be used to purchase two additional calves. Burma, 29, is married. Her husband is a construction worker specializing in carpentry and stonework. Burma has two daughters of pre-school age. Her family is engaged in farming and, this year, they are planning to grow potatoes. This loan will be used to purchase seeds. Altynbek, 35, is married and a father of two. His wife takes care of the house and raises the children. Altynbek is a carpenter, who sells custom-made items. He plans to use this loan to purchase live stock to raise and resell it later. Bermet, 33, is married. Her husband is a construction worker. Bermet farms land. She will use this loan to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer. Bermet and her husband will be repaying this loan together.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy livestock, seeds, and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Solidaridad Group

texts.es:
El grupo “SOLIDARIDAD”  esta conformado por 11 socias la Sra. Lucinda es la tesorera del grupo y llevan juntas varios años trabajando cada una en sus negocios, por su parte ella tiene un negocio D. venta D. pollo en un mercado D. la zona, su negocio tiene por nombre “AVICOLA CHARITO” fue su hermana quien le enseño a trabajar en este negocio empezaron juntas pero ahora lo hace ella sola y le va bien, su negocio ha crecido por que ella le da a sus clientes  valores agregados no solo venD. pollo sino también prepara milanesas, cortes especiales y otros pedidos que sus clientes le hacen. Con sus ganancias ha mejorado su  puesto D. trabajo haciendo algunas ampliaciones  para comodidad D. sus clientes, por otro lado su préstamo obtenido en "EDAPROSPO" lo utilizara para invertir en la compra D. huevos y gallina algo que añadirá en su negocio. Para mas adelante ella quisiera comprar el puesto donD. trabaja  por ahora  paga un alquiler mensual pero  esta ahorrando para que en un futuro comprarlo,lleva 10 años en este negocio y su constancia ha hecho que tenga mucho éxito.

*lA Sra. Lucinda es la primera D. las paradas esta con blusa blanca y lentes.
texts.en:
The “SOLIDARIDAD” ("Solidarity") group is maD. up of 11 members. Lucinda is the group's treasurer. The members have worked together for several years, each one pursuing her own business. For Lucinda's part, she has a business selling chicken in a local market. The name of her business is “AVICOLA CHARITO.” It was her sister who taught her how to work in this field; they started out together, but now Lucinda is running the business alone, and it is going very well for her. Her business has grown because she provides her customers with added value; she doesn't only sell chicken, but she also prepares cutlets, special cuts, and other orders that her customers request. With her profits, she has improved her stand, expanding it several times to better accommodate her customers. She will use the loan from "EDAPROSPO" to invest in buying eggs and hens, which she will add to the stock of her business. As time goes on, she would like to buy the stand where she works, since she currently pays monthly rent, but she is saving up to buy the stall in the future. She has operated this business for 10 years, and her perseverance has brought her much success. *In the photo, Lucinda is the first person standing up, with a white blouse and glasses.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying eggs and hens for her poultry business

loans.name: Evgeniy

texts.en:
Evgeniy is married with two children. He sells bed sheets and towels at one of the small markets in Zaporozhye city. Evgeniy has been in this business for seven years. Good communication skills and good choice of products help him a lot. Evgeniy enjoys his business very much and wants to develop it further.

Evgeniy has used microfinance loans before and found them very helpful. This time he would like to borrow 4,000 UAH to purchase more products. His goal is to be successful in both business and life.

loans.use: To purchase bed sheets and towels to sell

loans.name: Faiz Mai's Group

texts.en:
Faiz mai, age 47, lives in the city of Multan, a city famous for its shrines and sweetmeats. She has given birth to five children: four sons and a daughter. Faiz mai's husband, M. R., is a tailor and can stitch both gentlemen's and ladies' clothes. All their children are very talented. They are getting an education but are also learning tailoring skills from their father. 
 
The entire family operates a clothes sewing business. This is the major source of their income. They have been involved in this profession for the last 10 years.

Faiz mai has successfully repaid her two loans to Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Now she is applying again for a loan to buy another sewing machine in order to expand her clothes sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase another sewing machine for the family tailoring business

loans.name: Asmat's Group

texts.en:
Asmat is the wife of M. U. and comes from Multan, a city famous for its shrines and sweetmeats in Pakistan. She is 40 years old, married with two children: one son and one daughter. Her husband and her kids work at a photo frame-making business. They are very talented and can frame every picture. They also do calligraphy and then sell at markets and earn income. Their earning allows them to manage the financial expenses of the family. 

Asmat also operates her own decorative embroidery business. She makes embroidery on suits and earns profit. Her clientele base is made up of women. She receives order from her neighbors. Her earning allows her to share the financial burden of her family. 

She has successfully repaid two loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan again to purchase items (mirrors and paints and paint brushes) in bulk so her family can make more frames and make calligraphy and earn a good profit from it.

loans.use: Purchase items for her photo frame-making business

loans.name: Albiso

texts.en:
Albiso C. is from the village of Banigan, Liloy, Zamboanga d' Norte. She is 31 years old. Albiso is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Albiso owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Albiso has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Albiso joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Albiso has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Albiso is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Albiso from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen is the wife of U. D. and lives in a city called Multan, a city famous for its shrines and sweetmeats in Pakistan.  She is 50 years old and has a photo frame making business. She receives orders from gift shops and after completing the frames earns good income. She is a mother of six children: four sons and two daughters. Her first two sons help her with her frame-making business and the other children are enrolled in a school and getting an education. 

Her husband is a hawker. He specifically sells seasonal vegetables in his four-wheeled cart. He purchases the vegetables from the vegetable shops. He has been in this business for over 10 years. 

Parveen has successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a second loan to buy seasonal vegetables to expand her husband’s vegetable-selling business.

loans.use: Purchase seasonal vegetables to sell

loans.name: Bantilan

texts.en:
Bantilan M. is from the village of Antonino, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 48 years old. Bantilan is married and has 5 children. To make a living, Bantilan owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling beef products in the local community. Bantilan has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Bantilan joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bantilan is requesting a loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Bantilan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Preciosa

texts.en:
Preciosa S. is from the village of Antipolo. She is 63 years old. Preciosa is widowed and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Preciosa operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Preciosa has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Preciosa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Preciosa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets, livestock feed and other supplies. Preciosa is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Preciosa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Allah Rakhi's Group

texts.en:
Allah Rakhi is the wife of M. F. and they come from Multan, a city famous for its shrines and sweetmeats in Pakistan. 
She has three daughters and all of her daughters work in a photo frame-making business. They learnt this art from their mother Allah Rakhi. They earn a profit of Pak Rs. 9,000 every month which is a big help for their family. 

Allah Rakhi’s husband works at a sewing business. He runs his own tailoring shop in the community where he sews specifically men's clothes. His shop has become renowned among his customers.  

Allah Rakhi has successfully repaid her first loan to Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a second loan to purchase an electric sewing machine for her husband so he can sew clothes on time and earn a good profit.

loans.use: Purchase an electric sewing machine for sewing clothes

loans.name: Dionisia

texts.en:
Dionisia K. is from the village of Del Pilar. She is 46 years old, married and has 1 adult child.To make a living, Dionisia is engaged in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling copra and charcoal. She is also engaged in the agriculture sector, primarily in the planting of coconut and corn. Dionisia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities. 

 In 2004, Dionisia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dionisia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business . Dionisia is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to redeem their pawned land. This will be the 17th loan taken out by Dionisia from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: T o redeem their pawned land

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen is a widow and comes from Multan, a city famous for its shrines and sweetmeats in Pakistan. Her husband died of a heart attack. She was completely lost but she recovered herself for her children: one son and two daughters. Her husband was the only breadwinner for their family. 

After her husband's death she took over his responsibilities and started selling women's clothes. She purchased the clothes from cities (Faisalabad and Lahore) because of their cheap prices and good quality and sells in her community. Now her business is very famous in her neighborhood and she receives a lot of orders. 

She is applying for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) to purchase clothes in bulk to complete an order on time and earn good profit.

loans.use: Purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is married with one child. She sells children's clothing at an open-air market in Berdyansk town. Elena has been in this business for 6 years. She enjoys this business and manages it well. Elena has got a large variety of inventory and affordable prices. She is the only one who sells children's clothing at this particular market. Even though the economic crisis has decreased her sales, as Elena's loan officer says: Elena is a talented small business owner!

Elena would like to borrow 15,000 UAH to improve her business conditions. Elena hopes that a better looking kiosk will bring even more customers and increase sales.

loans.use: to improve business location

loans.name: Kyegwisa Bakyara Twimukye, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
A determined K. Ovia has, over the last six years, been successfully plying her spare-parts business in Ibanda town. With a monthly net profit of 80,000 shillings, this married lady has enjoyed the good graces that have come with running this lucrative business. Consequently she has made enormous progress in educating her six children.

Ovia’s first priority after acquiring this loan is to purchase more hardware stock with the sole objective of turning her business into a wholesale operation.

Ovia belongs to a group of members who hold each other accountable and insure one another in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To restock and expand her business

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is a 57-year-old woman and her husband's name is M. R.. She lives in a city named Multan famous for its shrines and sweetmeats in Pakistan. She is a very hard-working lady. She has a decorative embroidery business. Earlier she did this in her free time but later on she chose it as a profession and now she earns approximately Pak Rs. 15,000 from this business.

She has four kids: two sons and two daughters. She wants to raise her children with a good education and she utilizes her income to pay for their education expenses and to fulfill their needs. Her husband runs a grocery shop in the community to earn income. They both earn well to improve their living standards.
 
Nasreen is a regular client of Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). She has successfully repaid three loans to Asasah and now she is applying for a loan to purchase groceries to diversify her husband’s grocery shop into a store.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia B., 46, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Manuel B., a watch technician, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her variety store while also selling halo-halo (native Filipino dessert, made up of shaved ice, sweetened milk, a variety of sweet beans, shredded coconut, palm nuts, topped with sweetened jackfruit and caramel flan) peanut butter and charcoal. Her main customers are her neighbors who still are using the old ways of cooking.

Ofelia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 18,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying raw ingredients needed to continue production of her peanut butter. She also will invest some of the loan into her other businesses as additional capital to maintain operations of her store and her halo-halo stall.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be a stable source of income for her and her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying raw ingredients needed to produce peanut butter, etc.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en: Carmelita O. is from the village of Iligan City. She is 60 years old. Carmelita is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Carmelita manages a small eatery in the local community. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Carmelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Carmelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Zainab Mai's Group

texts.en:
Zainab Mai is a 27-year-old woman. She operates a clothes-sewing business at her house. Her clientele base is made up of women. She receives orders from neighbors and relatives and charges them between 100 and 150 Pakistan rupees. Her customers are completely satisfied with her stitching. They trust her stitching and never argue about their deadlines.

She has given birth to four children: one son and three daughters. All of them are getting a good education from the local school. Her husband's name is A. K. and he has been a mason for over 20 years. Their earnings help them to improve the living standards of their family.
 
She has successfully repaid her three loans to Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan and a Kiva partner). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy an electric sewing machine to complete more orders and to earn good profit.

loans.use: Purchase an electric sewing machine for sewing clothes

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria D. F. is from the village of Sawali Fuentes, Iligan City. She is 45 years old. Gloria is separated from her spouse and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Gloria runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Gloria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Gloria from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sajida Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Sajida Parveen is a 55-year-old married woman with one son. Her family live in a two-roomed brick house in the city of Multan, Pakistan, famous for its shrines and sweetmeats. She has lived there for the past 29 years.
For over 15 years, Sajida Parveen has run a business selling embroidered cloth. Her customers are from different cities such as Lahore, Islamabad and Faisalabad. She receives good orders from her customers and earns a good profit from them.
Her husband, H. N., is a motor mechanic. Together, their earnings help them to manage their family's financial expenses. Sajida Parveen is applying for a loan for the first time from Kiva partner, Asasah (a microfinance institution in Pakistan), to purchase more embroidered cloth to complete her customer orders.

loans.use: To purchase embroidered cloth for completing orders

loans.name: Polota Kakira Group Of Jinja

texts.en:
N. Margaret has been driving a hard bargain running her eight-year-old retail business in Jinja and doing some small-scale farming.

At its beginning, Margaret’s retail business was bringing her enormous profits, so much so that she managed to construct rental houses in Polota, Jinja. The 41-year-old married mother of four children says that throughout her eight-year experience, she has never wavered in her determination to succeed in whatever she sets out to do.

Margaret managed to zero-in early on the many inevitable financial and other operational business impediments that have manifested themselves. At length she has got to a point where she makes profits to the tune of 50,000 shillings a week. It’s in her future plans to buy a lorry (truck). This she hopes will help reduce the transport costs she has had to come to grips with in her years of operation.

With the acquisition of this loan, Margaret hopes to give her business a new lease of life through the purchase of new garments, electronics and edibles.

loans.use: To buy new garments, electronics and edibles for her business

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic P. is from the village of Sawale, Fuentes, Iligan City. She is 43 years old, widowed, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Marivic owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling beauty products and ready-to-wear items in the local community. Marivic has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Marivic joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marivic is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her third from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nagina Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Nagina Parveen is from the city of Multan in Pakistan, famous for its shrines and sweetmeats. She is 51 years old, married, and has four children – two sons and two daughters. Her younger son works in a local factory for a monthly wage, and her daughters are involved in an embroidered clothes business. Her elder son sells plastic utensils in different areas of Multan and generates profit from this business.
Nagina Parveen is a very caring lady. She stays at home and takes care of her family. She has given her children good manners and teaches them about discipline and respecting their elders. She has successfully repaid her two previous loans to Kiva partner, Asasah (a microfinance institution in Pakistan). Now, she is applying for a loan to purchase plastic utensils, such as cups and plates, in bulk to expand her elder son's business.

loans.use: To purchase plastic utensils to sell

loans.name: Herminia

texts.en:
Herminia D., of legal age, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. She is happily married to Alfredo D., a tricycle 9three-wheeled transport) driver. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been in the direct selling business for quite some time now. She mainly sells personal care products like lotions, perfumes and such.

Herminia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow three times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying advance orders of products in her cosmetics direct selling line.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education and able to buy a new tricycle unit.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying spare parts for tricycle and additional stocks for her direct selling business

loans.name: Kafunjo United Womens Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
Her business story began way back in 1994 in Kafunjo, Ibanda District. With hard work and determination, M. Edith has been able to run a grocery shop enterprise, dealing in fresh vegetables and fruits for sixteen years.

Due to her good customer care, Edith has been in position to maintain her business though with the drawback of having her goods rot since she lacks standard measures like using refrigerators.

With this loan Edith will be able to purchase more stock and also acquire refrigerators to keep her goods fresh longer. This will help her earn more revenue and enable her to meet her family requirements.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and also refrigerators

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion B. is from the village of  Sawali Fuentes, Iligan City. She is 35 years old. Concepcion is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Concepcion owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Concepcion has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Concepcion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Concepcion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Concepcion is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Concepcion from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en: Shamim is a young lady of 24 who lives in Multan, a city in Parkistan famous for its shrines and sweetmeats. Her husband, M. B., drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). He has been in this business for over five years. Shamim has a decorative embroidery business: she embroiders clothes for her neighbors and relatives. She does this work to improve her family's standard of living. Shamim is applying for a loan to buy materials (clothes, colored thread, and beads) to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy materials for her embroidery business

loans.name: Kucup Mekar Group

texts.en:
Ni Ketut P. (0) is a 49-year-old female living in the town of Melaya, Bali.  Ni Ketut is the group leader of an 18-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Kucup Mekar (MUK-0021).


Ni Ketut is married and has two adult children.  To making a living, Ni Ketut owns & operates a business raising pigs for sale.  Ni Ketut has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 150,000 IDR a month from these activities.


In 2010, Ni Ketut joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Ketut is requesting for the first time a loan from MUK of 1,300,000 IDR, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  The loan will be the first loan taken out by Ni Ketut from MUK.  Ni Ketut plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.


About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.





Ni Ketut P. (0) merupakan 49 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali.  Ni Ketut adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 18 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Kucup Mekar (MUK-0021).


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  Ni Ketut sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 2 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Ketut menghasilkan sekitar 150,000 IDR.  Dalam 2010, Ni Ketut bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Ni Ketut meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari MUK.    Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,300,000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.

loans.name: Khalida's Group

texts.en:
Khalida is a wife of M. A.. They live in the city of Lahore in Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods. Her house consists of two rooms in which she has lived with her family for over 15 years. She is the mother of a single daughter whose name is Samina and who reads in the 2nd standard educational level. Khalida has a wish to give her a good education so she has a good future. 

Khalida operates a decorative embroidery business. She receives orders from her neighbors and relatives. She beautifully set beads on clothes that no one can judge if it is made by machine or by hand. She earns approximately 10,000 Pakistan rupees in every month, which is a big source of support for her family. 

Her husband is involved in the wood-selling business. He has been in this profession for over 20 years. Now he has obtained a good reputation and a good customer list.
 
She is a regular client of Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan and a Kiva partner). She has successfully repaid her four loans to Asasah and is applying for the fifth time to purchase wood in bulk to expand her husband’s wood-selling business.

loans.use: Purchase wood in bulk to sell

loans.name: Hamidan's Group

texts.en:
Hamidan is a wife of K. Ali.  She lives in a city named Lahore, in Pakistan, which is famous for its historic places and its Punjabi foods.  She has two kids, one son and one daughter, both of whom are in kindergarten. Her husband works in a local factory where he prepares gentlemens’ pants & shirts. 

Hamidan is a very active lady. To generate income, she embroiders dresses which she then sells to clothing shops. Her embroidery attracts many customers, and as a result she has started getting orders from her neighbors, too.  She is applying for a loan to purchase items (clothes, beads and colored threads) in bulk to expand her embroidery business.

loans.use: to purchase items for her embroidery business

loans.name: Nieva

texts.en:
Nieva S., 51, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Jose S., a bus driver, Nieva is blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been into newspaper sales for quite some time now. She mainly buys and sells tabloids, newspapers and magazines.

Nieva has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow twelve times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she has used the money she has borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the continued success of her business, Nieva is applying for a PHP 40,000 loan. This money will be used to buy more magazines, newspapers and tabloids for selling. Nieva dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education, and have a long and comfortable life with her entire family.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more newspapers and magazines to incorporate into her current product inventory

texts.en: Narantsetseg is 33 years old and lives with her son in the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  Her son, Batbayr, attends a local secondary school. She is requesting a 400,000 tugrug (~ 285 USD) loan to expand her product line so she can sell consumer products including shampoo, toilet paper, tissues and soaps.
