texts.en:
Sriyani is a 38-year-old married woman living with her husband and no children. Her husband has a small steel business which she helps him with to support the family. Her husband also has another business; he owns a van for schools to hire.  

Sriyani and her husband are collecting pieces of iron to rebuild and sell. She wants to take a loan and improve their business. Four years ago she and her husband started this business. She is very enthusiastic and hardworking.

Sriyani has requested a 55,000 Sri Lankan rupee loan from BRAC to expand her business. She is grateful for BRAC because of the financial support it provides to her. She is a regular and active member within her BRAC small village organization.

loans.use: To develop the steel business

loans.name: Eva

texts.en: Eva is a married with four children.  She owns a roomed house where she stays with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Eva takes care of additional family members. She rents a shop where she sells charcoal from, selling to all categories of people both on retail and wholesale. She works seven days a week. Her business challenges includes transportation of charcoal  from villages to her place of work and rainy season.    She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. Eva‘s monthly expenses includes Food rents for her business premises and school fees . She is to boost her business of charcoal trade

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Hemalatha

texts.en:
Hemalatha is a 60-year-old widow living in the town of Hikkaduwa, in the Galle area of southern Sri Lanka with her brother. Since her mother and father died, Hemalatha started a sewing business which her brother provides some support to. She devotes her full effort towards developing her business. Hemalatha has managed her business for ten years now independently. In her business, she works hard and enjoys what she does. She sews dresses for villagers.

Hemalatha has asked for a 50,000 Sri Lankan rupee loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to buy a new sewing machine to expand her business. 

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Hodari Group

texts.fr:
Kapinga M.  est vice présidente du groupe de crédit  Hodari,géante avec sourire aux levres, elle lève sa main sur la photo, cliente au 11e cycle, âgée de 36 ans, veuve, mère de 7 enfants et tous étudient dans des écoles  normales  dont 3 à l’école  secondaire et 4 à l’école primaire. 
Son mari est  décedé  le 25 janvier 2005 à Kigali/Rwanda suite à une longue maladie de poumons. Pendant ces 5 ans, elle supporte seule la charge de ses enfants orphelins . 
Cette charge pèse lourdement  sur croissance rapide de son business.  
Son business est liberal, sans adresse et ambilatoire, elle  fournit des draps,des habits pour enfants, pagnes, boubous, bijoux en or aux différents preneurs  . Il y a 5 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité appelée "lutte-lutte pita pita".
Elle vivait au Rwanga/Kigali, où le gros de sa belle famille réside, après la mort de son mari, elle se vit sans aucune économie, elle a commencé à tisser les tricots, les napes, etc. Les revenus de ce petit métier(art) lui a permis de deplacer ses enfants orpheilns du Rwanda vers la RDCongo et les quelques  dollars qui sont restés d’une valeur de 50$ lui a permis de prendre un guest house pour s’installer. Elle a commencé à marchander avec les tomates, pétrol, sels, lait, savon en poudre OMO. Ensuite,elle fut informé de l’IMF Hekima qui donne des crédits  sans garentie, elle a béneficié le premier crédit de renforcement.
Lorsqu’ elle venait de retrouver l’équilibre, elle a été en nouveau victime d’une incendie du 08 juillet 2009 qui a brillé plus de 900 maisons dans la ville de Goma, dans le quartier populaire bidonville de Birere.
Avec  le crédit de  l’IMF Hekima, Kapinga M.   souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achétant  6 paires des draps, sizaine de chainettes d’or (localement appele Garentie manzanza), Sizaine de robes de qualité du Congo Brazza, 6 pagnes .
Kapinga M. est  également servante Evangeliste dans une eglise locale ‘’Chist est Roi” et parfois dans un ministrère chretien de réveil “Combat Spirituel”.
Kapinga  M. est confortable avec son business, dans l’avenir, elle planifie acheter une parcelle d’heritage pour ses enfants orphelins et finir avec le status de locataire de maison. En outre Kapinga M. revet voir tous ses enfants finir les études avec des diplômes qui leurs serviront dans le futur. 
Kapinga M. rémércie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grace à ces credits  lui permet  de subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants.
Enfin, Kapinga M.  a aisement trouvé le soulagement et l’équilibre  économique grace aux crédit s de Hekima, après la mort de son mari.
Le groupe de crédit  Hodari  est  composé de 15 membres majoritairement femmes.
texts.en:
Kapinga M. is vice-president of the Hodari credit loan group. A smiling giant of a woman (she is seen raising her hand on the picture), currently in her 11th loan cycle, she is a 36-year-old widow, the mother of seven children all attending school: four in the primary and three in the secondary school system. Her husband passed away 25 January 2005 in Kigali (Rwanda) following a prolonged lung-related illness. She has been the sole support of her children these past five years, which weighs heavily on the rapid expansion of her business. Her business is free-style in nature, itinerant without a fixed location. She provides bed sheets, children’s clothing, pagnes and boubous (colourful West-African clothing), and gold jewelry to all who are interested. It has now been five years since she began an activity known as “lutte-lutte pita pita”. She used to live in Kigali, where most of her in-laws reside, and following her husband’s death, without any savings, she began weaving clothes and tablecloths, etc. The earnings from this activity (craft) enabled her to move from Rwanda to the Democratic Republic of Congo with her children, where with her remaining $50 she was able to settle in a guesthouse. She started to trade in tomatoes, gasoline, salt, milk, powdered detergent (OMO). Then she learned that the Hekima MFI provided loans without collateral, and she was granted her first reinforcement loan. She had just re-established some financial balance when she became one of many victims of the 8 July 2009 fire that destroyed over 900 homes in Goma, inside the Birere shanty-town. With the Hekima MFI loan Kapinga M. wishes to increase her turnover by buying 6 pairs of bedsheets, a half-dozen gold chains (locally called “Garantie manzanza”), a half-dozen quality dresses from Congo Brazzaville, and six pagnes. She is also an Evangelist acolyte in a local church (Christ is King) and sometimes participates in “Spiritual Combat”, a Christian revivalist ministry. She is comfortable with how her business is going, and in the future envisions buying a plot of land as inheritance for her children and eventually renting out as a property owner. Additionally she hopes to see all of her children finish their studies with diplomas that will serve them in their future. Kapinga M. thanks the Hekima MFI for the loans she has received without any collateral because that is what enabled her to meet her children’s needs. She was finally able to enjoy relief and financial stability for the first time since her husband’s death, thanks to Hekima’s loans. The Hodari loan group is made up of 15 members, for the most part women.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 6 pairs of bedsheets, 6 guaranteed gold chains, 6 quality dresses from Congo Brazzaville, and 6 pagnes

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Milly

texts.en: Milly is a married with six children and her children go to school. She owns a two-room house where she stays with eight people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Milly takes care of additional family members (her sister). Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. Milly owns a store where she sells charcoal near her home. She sells to all categories of people both at retail and at wholesale . She works seven days a week. Milly receives at least for 30 customers a day she has been in this business for ten years and her business challenges include seasonality and defaulters.  Besides this charcoal business, she also rears chicken at her home.  She has been with MCDT for many years servicing her 13th loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal and chicken feed.  She is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and go directly to producers.  She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with low income women. She aspires to get a better standard of living and educate her children up to university level

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal and chicken feeds

loans.name: Bayarjargal

texts.en:
Bayarjargal is 38 years old and lives with her husband and five children in Zavhan province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Four of her children, age 11-17, attend local secondary and primary schools. 

Bayarjargal operates a traditional Mongolian boot manufacturing business with her husband. They produce boots for men, women and children. Bayarjargal and her husband have been operating their business since July 2009, and have become experienced at shoe manufacturing. They have built a loyal customer base. Bayarjargal usually sells her products for cash, although she sometimes barters her boots for meat and dairy products. The cost of her boots depends on how many ornaments are included in a pair. Children's boots cost 10,000 – 15,000 tugrugs (~  7 – 10 USD), and adult boots cost between 60,000 and 80,000 tugrugs (~  42 – 60 USD). Bayarjargal and her husband have the capacity to produce 4-5 pairs of boots per month. Their monthly profit is 80,000 – 150,000 tugrugs (~  60 – 110 USD). Bayarjargal is a very hardworking person and has many plans for the future. She says, “I would like to expand my business and purchase my own plot of land with a yard.” 

She is requesting a 150,000 tugrug (~  110 USD) loan to purchase leather and other materials used to manufacture Mongolian boots.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase salon materials like shampoo, hair driers and other items

loans.name: Ruhini Priyadarsha

texts.en:
Ruhini Priyadarsha is a 32-year-old married woman living with her husband and three children. She has one son and two daughters. They live in the town of Hikkaduwa, in the Galle area of southern Sri Lanka. Her husband has a motor boat, which he uses daily in his fishing business. Ruhini is providing good help to her husband selling fish. She helps to handle the family expenses instead of just relying on her husband to do so. Ruhini has been doing this business for 10 years.

Ruhini has requested a 35,000 Sri Lankan rupee loan from BRAC to renovate the fishing boat.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To renovate boat

loans.name: Birleshan

texts.en:
Birleshan is 51 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Bayn-Ulgii province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Two of his children, Jagslag and Ainur, are university students. His youngest son, Bekbolat, is a secondary school student. 

Currently, Birleshan operates a clothing trading business with his wife at a local market, called Tirlik. They have been operating their business since 1998, have steadily expanded their business and have become experienced traders over the past twelve years. Birleshan purchases fashionable and modern clothing for his young customers. He and his wife have built a loyal customer base because of their good selection of products and excellent communication skills. He purchases his products once a month for 300,000 – 600,000 tugrugs (~ 215 - 430 USD). Birleshan's daily sales are 80,000 – 120,000 (~ 60 - 85 USD). His average monthly profit is 200,000 – 400,000 tugrugs (~  142 – 285 USD). Birleshan is an honest person who has a great business mind. He says, “I don't like to delay today's work to tomorrow. Today is today, tomorrow is tomorrow.” 

He is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug (~ 2860 USD) loan to purchase more inventory in Taikeshken, a Chinese border town.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric G. is from the village of Digkilaan, Iligan City. He is 34 years old. Eric is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Eric owns & operates a business providing motorcycle services used to transport passengers to the local community. Eric has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Eric joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Eric has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. Eric is requesting a new loan of 18000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 9th loan taken out by Eric from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Ariunselenge

texts.en:
Ariunselenge is 37 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. All of her three children attend a local secondary school. 

Ariunselenge operates a traditional Mongolian dress (Deel) manufacturing business in her town. She produces custom-made deels to sell to her many customers. Ariunselenge has been succesfully operating her business since 2008. She has been planning to expand her business in order to pay the university fees of her children and to improve her family's quality of life. Besides manufacturing deels, Ariunselenge also employs a salesperson who sells fabric and materials at the local Ihbuyan market. Ariunselenge is a very hardworking person and is focused on the future. She says, “My dream is that one day I will create my own tailoring center.” 

She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~ 360 USD) loan to purchase fabric and other materials necessary for her business.

loans.use: To purchase material.

loans.name: Raeva Aytbu`s Group

texts.ru:
Айтбу, 48 лет, она замужем и мать 4 детей. Все дети взрослые. С ней вместе проживает ее сын со своей супругой. Супруг  и сын работают строителями, невестка занимается животноводством и реализацией молочной продукции.Клиент откармливает двух доенных коров и двух телок, также реализует молочные продукции. Планирует уехать на пастбище где пасут живность населения. Бизнес был начат с 3-х МРС, клиентка была заинтересована в разведении КРС. Клиент на кредит планирует закупить еще одну доенную корову и увеличить обьем реализации молочной продукции. 

Шарбатхан, 46, вдова. У нее трое детей. Старшая дочь замужем, остальные дети учатся в школе. Клиент в данное время подгатавливает землю для посева хлопчатника. Кредит необходим для закупа семян хлопчатника и минеральные удобрение для орашения.

Гулзаде 28 лет. Ее супруг работает строителем и помогает в бизнесе при запасе корма для живности. Клиент также работает в школе учительницей начальных классов. Кредит юудет использован для закупа доенной коровы для откорма и увеличения поголовья КРС.

Мира, 33, она откармливает доенную корову и телку, также занимается  занимается реализацией молочной продукции. Ее супруг строитель. Старшие дети идут в школу, за младшим сыном присматривает дочь дома. Бизнес был начат с откорма и разведения 3-х КРС, далее заинтересовалась в разведении КРС. Она хочет купить еще одного теленка для разведения и увеличить обьем реализации молочных продукций.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Aytbu is 48 years old. She is married and a mother of 4 children. All of her children are grown. Her son and daughter-in law live with her. Aytbu’s husband and son are construction workers, and daughter-in-law is involved in animal husbandry and sales of dairy products. Aytbu is currently fattening up two dairy cows and two heifers. She also sells dairy products. She plans to travel to a pasture where locals take their livestock. Aytbu started the business with 3 small livestock, and the client was interested in breeding cattle. The client plans to use this loan to buy one more dairy cow and increase the volume of dairy products sales. Sharbathan is 46 years old. She is a widow and has three children. The oldest daughter is married, and the other children go to school. Currently, the client is getting the soil ready for sowing of cotton. The loan is needed for the purchase of cotton seeds and mineral fertilizers. Gulzada is 28 years old. Her husband is a construction worker and also helps with the business by stocking livestock feed. The client also works as an elementary grades teacher at a school. The loan will be used for the purchase of a dairy cow for fattening and increasing cattle headcount. Mira is 33 years old. She is fattening up a dairy cow and a heifer and is also involved in selling dairy products. Her husband is a construction worker. The oldest children go to school, and Mira’s daughter looks after the youngest child at home. The business was started with fattening and breeding of 3 cows, and Mira became more interested in breeding cattle. She wants to buy one more calf for breeding and increase the volume of sales of dairy products.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of one dairy cow

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina Y. is from the village of Digkilaan, Iligan City. She is 40 years old. Gina is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Gina makes and sells food. The main source of income for her business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Gina has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Gina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Gina is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Gina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en:
Batbayar is 23 years and lives with his parents and a sibling in Hovd province, Mongolia. His father works for a private company and his sibling attends a local secondary school. Currently, Batbayar operates a consumer electrical products and auto repair service. He is certified as a television repairman and an electrician, and has been working in his chosen profession  for three or four years. 

In addition to his electronics repair business, Batbayar has been operating an auto repair service since 2009. He is a very hardworking person, and has many plans for the future. Batbayar says, “My dream is to one day open my own auto and electrical products repair center.” 

He is requesting a 450,000 tugrug loan to purchase machinery and spare parts for his business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts

loans.name: Prema

texts.en:
Prema is a 48-year-old married woman and lives with her husband, one daughter, and son.  She works hard and places her priority on operating her business.

Prema's business involves making carpets, and she has a lot of experience with this type of business. Currently, she makes only thirty carpets per day. There is strong competition in her area for selling carpets, because Hikkaduwa is a popular tourist destination.  There is a strong demand from foreign tourists for 'prefix carpets' (carpet mats stitched together from previously discarded textiles). Prema's husband helps her by delivering and selling them to customers, which greatly helps the business.

Prema has requested a 40,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka which she will use to buy raw materials and develop the carpet business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for carpet business

loans.name: God Will Provide Group

texts.en: Mickey T. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Will Provide. He is 34 years old and married with two children who are 2 and 7 years old. He also cares for his mother and a sister. He is a high school graduate but could not continue his education through college due to poverty. For 11 years, he has been selling used clothes at the Vai town market close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia. Mickey started selling with 14,000 Liberia dollars he got from his friends. He always sells good used things and he sells them on time in order encourage customers to continue returning. Mickey plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more used clothes for sale. He dreams of building a shop and becoming an importer. His goal is to educate his children and build more houses for his family. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mickey is the one holding the sign and Miatta is in the inset photo in the lower right corner. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes for sale

loans.name: Naajav

texts.en:
Naajav is 41 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband is an electrician for a private company. One of her daughters attends a university, and other two children attend a local secondary school. 

Naajav operates a food products trading business at a local food market, called Han-Ord. She has been operating her business since 2004, and has steadily expanded her business. Naajav purchases her products from a local central market to save money on transportation. In addition, when her friends or relatives go to Russia or Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, they bring back products for her, which also saves her money. She has previously received an 800,000 tugrug (~ 570 USD) loan, which she used to triple the size of her business. Naajav is a open person and focused on the future. She says, “The most important thing for me is to provide a good education for my children and to be able to pay their university fees until they graduate.” 

Naajav is requesting a 2,700,000 tugrug (~  1930 USD) loan to purchase a variety of food products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of food products.

loans.name: Arnelito

texts.en:
Arnelito W. is from the village of Rogondon Iligan City. He is 42 years old. Arnelito is married and has 8 school-aged children. To make a living, Arnelito owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Arnelito and his wife has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Arnelito joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Arnelito is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Arnelito from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: United Sisters And Brothers Group

texts.en:
Mary W. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called United Sisters and Brothers. She is 38 years old, married and has five children who range in age, from 3 to 19 years old. She could not continue her education through high school.

For 8 years, Mary has been selling fried fish, cucumbers and cola nuts at the Somalia Drive in Monrovia, Liberia.
She gives her customers kind words during sales and sometimes shares a laugh with them, in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.
Mary started selling with 500.00 Liberian Dollars as working capital. She now has 3000.00 Liberian Dollars as working capital.
She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000.00 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more fish and flour. Her goal is to grow her business to a higher size and to see her family live an improved life.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mary is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more fish and flour.

loans.name: Trust Group

texts.en:
Genevive S. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Trust. She is 39 years old, married and has four children who range in age from 7 to 20 years old. She could not continue her education through the 7th grade.
For 15 years, Genevive has been selling engine oil, kerosene, soaps and toothpaste at the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia.
She sells goods that are high in demand and talks to her customers in a nice manner, in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.
Genevive started selling with a little amount of cash. She now has an improved size of business at the Redlight market.
She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 39,000.00 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more engine oil, kerosene and soap. Her goal is to grow her business to a better size and to improve the living conditions of her family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Genevive is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more engine oil, kerosene and soap.

loans.name: Cerila

texts.en:
Cerila E. is from the village of Rogongon, Iligan City. She is 40 years old. Cerila has 9 school-aged children. To make a living, Cerila owns & operates a  sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Cerila has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cerila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Cerila is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Cerila from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Manita

texts.en:
Manita V. is a 60-year-old widow who lives in Montilla, Moises Padilla, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by engaging in selling fermented small fish (Ginamos). She also buys and sells livestock.

Manita has seven adult children who are between 24-40 years old. Some of the children have their own families and the others are gainfully employed and help support the needs of the family.

Manita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 in the hope that she would be able to help improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in selling of fermented small fish and buy and sell of livestock. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000 from her business activities.

Manita is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 was used to fund operations of her business activities - selling fermented fish (ginamos) and livestock, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing  PHP 25,000 for her 16th loan, which she intends to use to purchase inventory for her businesses. Manita is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. The photo of Manita was taken after the weekly center meeting.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additional working capital

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en: Deborah is a married with seven  children and all her children  now finished school. She owns a roomed house where she stays with eight people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Deborah takes care of additional family members.  Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. Deborah is a fishmonger in Nakulabye selling all types of smoked fish ranging from Tilapia, Nile perch and seas fish and sells to all categories of people both at retail and at wholesale. She works seven days a week. Deborah receives at least for 20 customers a day she has been in this business for a few months  and her business challenges include seasonality and transport of fish from Gaba landing site to her place of work. Formerly Deborah was dealing in Charcoalbut changed her business enterprise to fish selling.   She has been with MCDT for many years servicing her 11th loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more baskets of fish.  She aspires to see her business grow bigger and start selling on wholesale only. She aspires to build rental houses

loans.use: To buy more baskets of fish

loans.name: Bulamu Development Group Of Mityana

texts.en:
With seven children of his own and two dependents to take care of, 39-year-old hardworking W. Joseph knows he has his responsibilities cut out for him. This reality has looked him in the face for the past seven years as he goes about his trivial-round business of tea packing in Kakonde, Mityana.

With his minimal 240,000 shillings monthly earnings, Joseph has faced long odds in providing for all his family’s needs, principally his children’s education. He wants to improve the status quo of his family with the acquisition of this loan. He wants to give his business an improved lease of life by buying packing boxes for his tea leaves.

loans.use: To buy packing boxes for his tea leaves

loans.name: Liza

texts.en: Liza P. is from the village of Rogongon, Iligan City. She is 38 years old. Liza is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Liza runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Liza has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2010, Liza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Liza from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Macaria

texts.en:
Macaria S. is a 43-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy 5, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by providing desktop publishing services to her community.

Macaria’s husband Reynante helps his wife run their computer printshop business. They have four children who are between 15-23 years old. Three of their children are currently going to school and help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores and one child already has a family and a child. 

Macaria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she wanted to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a computer-aided printing business. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 7,000 from her business activities.

Macaria is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 was used to fund operations of her business, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing PHP 15,000 for her 14th loan, which she intends to use expand the services she provides to her customers. Macaria is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Gbodeman Group

texts.en: Edwin G. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Gbodeman Group. He is 43 years old, married and has four children who range from 5 to 22 years old. He could not continue his education through 9th grade due to the Liberian civil crisis. For three years, Edwin has been selling provisions at the Pipelines Catholic Junction in Paynesville, Liberia. He sells goods that customers want to buy in order to encourage them to continue buying from him. Edwin started selling on a table with few goods but now sells in a shop with lots of goods. He sometimes faces problems with customers buying on credit without paying on time, which is not good for business. Edwin plans to use his 9,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 41,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more provisional goods. His goal is to grow his business to expand to other communities in Monrovia. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Edwin is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more provisional goods

loans.name: Hemawathi

texts.en:
Hemawathi is 57 years old, married and living with her husband and 3 children.  They live in the town of Hikkaduwa in the Galle area of Sri Lanka, on the southern coast of the island. Her husband and eldest son run a small fishing business, which she provides support to.  Hemawathi wants to help them purchase a fishing net with this loan.  Her other children are educated.  Hemawathi and her family have a lot of experience in the fishing business.

Hemawathi has requested a 40,000 LKR loan for the fishing business from BRAC to help her husband and son.  She is grateful for BRAC because of the support it provides to her.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase a fishing net

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia G. is a 57-year-old widow who supports her family by running a general store, and selling rice and charcoal at retail to her neighbors. She lives in Brgy 5, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental with her two adult children who are 33 and 36 years old. Both of her children are married.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, rice and charcoal retailing businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000.

Ofelia is now borrowing PHP 19,000 so that she can continue her general store, and sustain her rice and charcoal retailing business. This will be her 19th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ofelia aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additional working capital

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita M. is a 41-year-old married woman with five children who lives in Sitio Macasayang, Brgy Mabini, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. Amelita has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for 10 years now and earns a living by running a general store business. She is purchasing a solar lantern with a PHP 3,100 loan from NWTF to extend her productive hours and, at the same time cut fuel costs, and save money in the long run.		

About NWTF’s Green Loan Products:
Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation believes that the key to poverty alleviation for the poorest is to provide services beyond just credit.  To that end, NWTF offers green energy products designed to save money for its clients.  In a partnership with SunTransfer and Arc Finance, NWTF distributes solar-powered lanterns that also function as a charging station for mobile phones. These families normally use kerosene lamps to light their homes.  The solar lantern offers a free, environment-friendly renewable source of energy, that allows them to reduce their monthly fuel costs.   

About NWTF:

loans.name: Diolenda

texts.en: Diolenda B. is a 55 year old married woman with 9 children who lives in Barangay Mabini, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. Diolenda has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for 3 years now and earns a living by running a sugarcane farm and running a general store business. She is purchasing a solar lantern with a PHP 3,100 loan from NWTF to extend her productive hours and at the same time cut fuel costs and save money in the long run. texts.en: Emma S. is a 57 year old married woman with 4 children who lives in Sitio Macasayang, Barangay Mabini, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. Emma has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for 3 years now and earns a living by running a general store business. loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en: Kou T. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called In God We Trust. She is 41 years old, married and has four children who range from 12 to 18 years old. She could not continue her education through 9th grade. For 20 years, Kou has been selling peanuts, plantains and sugar at the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia. She sells goods that customers need in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Kou started by selling at home but now sells in the market. She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 40,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more peanuts and sugar. Her goal is to grow her business to a better size and improve the living conditions of her family. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kou is the one holding the sign and Oretha is in the inset photo in the lower right corner. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more peanuts and sugar

loans.name: Adela

texts.en: Adela A. is a 66 year old single woman who supports her family by running a general store business. She lives in Washington St., Poblacion Dauin, Negros Oriental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since June 24, 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. Adela is now borrowing PHP 12,000 for her general store business. This will be her 25th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 22,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Adela aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additonal working capital

loans.name: Ahmadalieva Sobirahon`s Group

texts.ru:
Собирахон 51 лет. Она разведенная мать 3 детей. У нее есть один сын и двое дочерей-близняшки.Сын частный водитель, дочери на заработках в РФ. Клиент занимается животноводством: откорм и разведение овец и реализация молочных продуктов. Клиентка ранее работала в г. Мархамат в Хлопчатобумажном комбинате, после того как закрыли границу она стала дома разводить овец, сын закупал и откармливал, через месяц продавал.Сейчас она хочет закупить 10 овец и отправить на пастбище.

Мавлюдахон, 51, замужем. Ее супруг частный строитель. Старший сын на заработках в РФ, старшая дочь помощница в бизнесе, две младшие школьники. Она вместе с семьей занимается животноводством, откорм и разведения и реализация молочной продуктов. Бизнес был начат с того, что продав овца закупили корову, затем стали реализовывать молоко. Доход был хорошим. Она в день реализует 7-8 лт молока, доход в месяц составляет 80 долларов. Кредит будет использован для закупа строй материалы для стройки дома.

Сайерахон 40 лет. Она вдова с 4 детьми. Старший сын помогает матери по бизнесу и хозейству, средний сын работает в чайхане, младший сын и дочь учатся в школе. Они занимаются животноводством.В 2008 году продав телку закупила беременную корову, которая после пол года родила теленка. Настоящее время клиентка активно занимается реализацией молока.Она хочет закупить 300 кг цемента и другие строй материалы для ремонта дома, также купить корм для живности на кредит.

Осудахон, 45, замужем. Ее супруг строитель.Дочь Дилором зарабатывает в г.Бишкек в швейном цехе, старший сын помогает по хозяйству, младший ходит в школу.'Она выращивает и реализует хлопок.Сейчас планирует закупить мин. удобрения и семена хлопчатника, также купить ГСМ для распашки земли.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Sobirahon is 51 years old. She is a divorced mother of 3 children. She has one son and two twin daughters. Her son is private driver, and the daughters are working in Russia. The client is involved in animal husbandry: feeding and breeding sheep and selling dairy products. The client previously worked in the town of Marhamat at a cotton manufacturing factory, and after the border was closed, she started breeding sheep at home. Her son bought and fattened the livestock and sold it a month later. Now, Sobirahon wants to buy 10 sheep and send them to a pasture. Mavludahon is 51 years old, married. Her husband is a construction contractor. The oldest son is working in Russia, oldest daughter is an assistant in the business, and the two youngest daughters are in school. Mavludahon and her family are involved in animal husbandry, feeding and breeding and sales of dairy products. The business was started with a sale of one sheep and purchase of a cow and then grew into dairy products sales. The income was good. Mavludahon sells 7-8 liters of milk per day, and her monthly income is 80 dollars. The loan will be used for the purchase of construction materials to build a house. Sayorahon is 40 years old. She is a widow and has 4 children. The oldest son helps his mother with the business and household, the middle son works at a teahouse, and the youngest son and daughter go to school. They are involved in animal husbandry. Sayorahon, having sold a cow in 2008, bought a pregnant cow, who birthed a calf half of a year later. Currently, the client is actively involved in sales of dairy products. She wants to buy 300 kg of cement and other construction materials in order to repair her house. She also wants to buy livestock feed. Osudahon is 45 years old, married. Her husband is a construction worker. Her daughter, Dilorom, works at a sewing factory in Bishkek, oldest son helps with the household, and the youngest goes to school. Osudahon grows and sells cotton. Currently, she plans to buy mineral fertilizers and cotton seeds and also fuel for plowing the land.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 10 sheep

loans.name: Jayawathi

texts.en:
Jayawathi  is 47 years old and married, living with her husband and one 24-year-old daughter.  Her husband has a timber business, in which he uses a chainsaw to cut and sell timber.  Jayawathi assists him with this as well as with her own venture involving coir-making.  Jayawathi and her husband make a good team and work together in their businesses.  Both of them have a lot of experience, as she has managed her business for 12 years and her husband has managed his for 10 years.  Jayawathi is an honest and hard-working lady.

Jayawathi has asked for a 40,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to assist her husband's timber business.  Pictured above are Jayawathi and her husband.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop the timber business

loans.name: Kanthi

texts.en:
Kanthi is a 48-year-old married woman living with her husband and 3 children, aged from sixteen to twenty-four.  They live in the town of Hikkaduwa, on the southern coast of Sri Lanka.  

She and her husband have a business in which they sell firewood.  Kanthi and her husband are running the business with good help; it has now been in operation for 10 years.  Kanthi is an active lady and she and her husband make a very good team in their business.

She has requested a 40,000 LKR loan from BRAC to help expand the business and buy a new machine to help split firewood.  They hope to continue to see success and increased profits from the new machine.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: to purchase a new firewood splitting machine

loans.name: Burhanova Tolkun`s Group

texts.ru:
Толкун, 63 года. Она вдова и мать 2 детей.Старший сын работает в РОВД, младший сын занимается наемной работой. Она активно занимается сельским хозяйством, имеет парник где выращивает саженцы помидора и планирует посадить их на своей земле. Кредит нужен для закупа телки для откорма и реализации.

Турсунали, 41, вдовец. У него 7 детей.Сыновья занимаются сельским хозяйством и перепродажей овощей. Невестки присматривают за детьми и помогают в бизнесе.Клиент сам откармливает 4х овец, 17 кур, подготавливает землю к посеву.На кредит он планирует закупить одного бычка и закупить минеральные удобрения для земледелия.

Адолатхон 64 года. Ее супруг пенсионер и присматривает за хозяйством.У нее 4 детей. Старший сын преподаватель в училище, младший сын работает охраником ТЭЦ, невестки активно помогают в бизнесе.На 0,20 га посадили картофель, на 0,41 га планируют посадить помидоры, дома имеют парник, где разводят саженцы помидоров. На кредит планирует закупить минеральные удобрения для картофеля и помидоров, а также манеж для новорожденной дочки.

Кенжехан 61, ее супруг также пенсионер. У нее 6 детей.Старший сын тракторист, младший сын занимается оптовой перепродажей овощей и фруктов, невестки занимаются с/х. В день визита готовили зелень на продажу. На 0,20 га посадили капусту 8000 шт., на остальное 0,25 га планируют посадить помидоры. За счет кредита она планирует расширить бизнес и  увеличить поголовья КРС.

texts.en:
Tolkun is 63 years old. She is a widow and a mother of 2 children. The oldest son works at the District Department of Internal Affairs, youngest son is involved in contract work. Tolkun is actively involved in agriculture, has a greenhouse, where she started growing tomatoes and plans to re-plant them on her land. She needs the loan for the purchase of a cow for fattening and subsequent resale. Tursunali is 41 years old, a widower. He has 7 children. The sons are involved in agriculture and resale of vegetables. Daughters-in-law look after their children and help with the business. The client is raising four sheep, 17 chickens and preparing the land for sowing. He plans to use the loan to buy one bull and mineral fertilizers for treating the soil. Adolathon is 64 years old. Her husband is retired and looks after the household. She has 4 children. The oldest son is a college teacher, youngest son works as a security guard at the thermoelectric plant, and daughters-in-law actively help with the business. They planted 0.20 hectares with potatoes and plant to plant 0.41 hectares with tomatoes. They have a greenhouse at home where they started to grow tomatoes. Adolathon plans to use the loan to buy mineral fertilizers for potatoes and tomatoes and also to buy a newborn crib. Kenjehan is 61 years old. Her husband is also retired. She has 6 children. The oldest son is a tractor driver, youngest son is involved in wholesale sales of vegetables and fruits, and the daughters-in-law are involved in agriculture. They were preparing greens for sale on the day of the visit. They planted 8000 pieces of cabbage on 0.20 hectares and plan to plant tomatoes on the remaining 0.25 hectares. Kenjehan plans to use the loan to expand the business and increase cattle headcount.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a cow

loans.name: Suvineetha

texts.en:
Suvineetha  is a 45-year-old married woman living with her kids, 16 years and 13 years old. Last year her husband went abroad, so she manages her business herself.

Suvineetha has a work place where she weaves hats for local customers.  She started this business two years ago, and she is very enthusiastic about it. She cooperates well with others and is always in a positive mood.

Suvineetha has requested a 40,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to purchase raw materials for her business. She is grateful to BRAC Sri Lanka because of the financial support it provides her.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for woven hats

loans.name: Seguku A Tibita Medius Group

texts.en:
Tibita M. is a hardworking businesswoman. She is 39 years old. Tibita is a married mother of six children who are schooling. She has dealt in the banana business since the year 1998. 

Tibita is using the loan to purchase bananas from Mbarara district to sell in Kampala, specifically in Seguku. Her dream is to improve upon her business.

loans.use: To purchase bananas

loans.name: Akimova Mahsuda`s Group

texts.ru:
Махсуде 48 лет. Она замужем и мать 3 детей.Дочь замужем, воспитывает детей, сыновья на заработках в РФ. Супруг работает врачом - хирург, зарплата около 120 долларов.Заемщица дома откармливает 2 коровы и разводит 13 овец.На кредит она хочет закупить овец для откорма и разведения.

Маликахон, 48, ее супруг работает инспектором РайОНО.'Старшие дочери замужем, младшая дочь дома, сын окончил школу настоящее время обучается в ВУЗе, младший учится в школе. Клиент же занята животноводством, откормом и разведением КРС, также реализует молочную продукцию (дома имеется доенная корова). Клиентка ранее занималась с/х, получив хороший доход от посеянного лука, закупила беременную корову. Сейчас она закупит телку для разведения.

Мендайым 49 лет. Она замужем, ее супруг член крестьянского хозяйства. У нее трое сынове. Старшие сыновья находятся на заработках в РФ, младший учится в школе.Она занимается торговлей, розничная реализация продуктов питания.Ранее клиентка занималась с/х, но в 1999 году соседка посоветовала возле дома открыть небольшой киоск, чтобы получить дополнительный доход. На кредит она планирует расширить ассортимент реализуемой продукции.
 
Саламат, 55, мать 3 детей. Клиентка имеет возле дома торговую точку с оборотом около 250 долларов. Супруг Частный водитель, заработок в месяц 100 долларов. Она хочет увеличить товарооборот т.е. купить товары для повседневного спроса.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Mahsuda is 48 years old. She is married and a mother of 3 children. Her daughter is married and raising children. The sons are working in Russia. Mahsuda’s husband works as a surgeon, whose salary is about 120 dollars. At home, Mahsuda is fattening up 2 cows and breeding 13 sheep. She wants to use the loan to buy sheep for fattening and breeding. Malikahon is 48 years old. Her husband works as an inspector at the district education department. The oldest daughters are married, youngest daughter is at home, son finished school and currently attends a university, and the youngest goes to school. The client is involved in animal husbandry, fattening and breeding cattle, and also sells dairy products. She has a dairy cow at home. The client was previously involved in agriculture, and having gotten a good income from onions she grew, she bought a pregnant cow. Now, she will purchase a cow for breeding. Mendayim is 49 years old. She is married, and her husband is a member of an agricultural collective. She has three sons. The oldest sons work in Russia, and the youngest goes to school. Mendayim is involved in sales, specifically retail sales of food products. Previously, the client was involved in agriculture, but her neighbor suggested opening a small store near home in 1999 in order to have a supplemental income. She plans to use the loan to expand the variety of products that she sells. Salamat is 55 years old. She is a mother of 3 children. The client has a retail outlet near her home that has a turnover of about 250 dollars. Her husband is a private driver, whose monthly salary is 100 dollars. Salamat wants to increase goods turnover, i.e. buy goods of everyday demand.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a sheep

loans.name: Karidia

texts.fr:
Née le 10 Août 1975 à Sikasso, Karidia B. est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Wayerma II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Karidia B. est une aide soignante de formation qui n’a jamais exercé cette profession. Elle s’est plutôt initiée et s’installée dans les activités d’achat et de vente d’articles divers de boutique dont elle dispose une  devant le domicile conjugal où elle mène cette activité d’achat et vente  d’articles divers tels, les eaux minérales,  des œufs, les Cigarettes,  les bonbons, allumettes, Chewing-gum, lait en poudre, Thé, sucre, etc il y a environ 4 ans. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant trois ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association BENKADI de Wayerma I), elle est à son troisième prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 4 cartouches de Cigarettes différentes,10 paquets de Chewing-gum, 2 cartons de lait en poudre (en sachets), 10 gros paquets du thé, 1 sacs du sucre, 6 alvéoles d'œuf   , 10 paquets de bonbon, 4 cartons de l’eau DIAGO, 20 paquets d’allumette, etc. 
Elle achète ses marchandises chez les commerçants grossistes de place avant de les revendre en détail au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée des voisins et surtout des jeunes..
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born 10 August 1975 in Sikasso, Karidia B. is married and mother of three children. She lives with her husband and their children in Wayerma II, one of several populous neighborhoods in Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mrs. Karidia B. is a trained caregiver who has never practiced as such. Four years ago she began trading various items she sells in a store located in the front of her home: mineral water, eggs, cigarettes, candy, matches, chewing-gum, powdered milk, tea, sugar, etc. She is quite in demand by her customers for the quality of her products. To satisfy an increasing number of customers, she decided three years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI. After four group loans in a neighbourhood women’s association (the Benkadi Association of Wayerma I), she is now requesting a third individual loan. All preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed. With this loan she will buy: four cartons of various cigarettes, 10 packages of chewing-gum, two cartons of powdered milk (in bags), 10 large packages of tea, one bag of sugar, 10 packages of sweets, four cartons of Diago mineral water, 20 matchboxes, etc. She gets her supplies from local wholesalers before selling them retail, for cash or credit, to customers from the area and particularly the young. She hopes to reach monthly earnings of 200,000 FCFA which will be used to increase her working capital, share family expenses, reimburse her loan and invest the remainder in her business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various general store products

loans.name: Seguku A Lubwama Teddy Group

texts.en: L. Teddy is a single mother of three children, two of whom are going to school. She has a charcoal business that she has been operating for over five years. Previously, she could purchase only ten or fewer bags of charcoal at a time, but now she will use the loan to purchase fifty or more bags to sell. Her business is growing like wild fire. She is encouraged to work very hard. Her hope for the future is to construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase fifty bags of charcoal at a time to sell.

loans.name: Champion. Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Champion sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 45ans, 5 enfants et vivant dans des  familles polygames à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de condiments alimentaires, d’atiecké et de tissus à l’image de Mariam Cissé.
Avec son  prêt, Mariam Cissé compte acheter,  20 rouleaux de tissus. 
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville et au Burkina Faso, un pays frontalier du Mali. Elle effectue ses ventes dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant. 
 Tandis que Mariam  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.000FCFA, les autres membres du groupe espèrent obtenir 12.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Champion ambitionnent d’augmenter leur chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire leur clientèle.
texts.en:
The five members of the Champion group are married women, and are on average 45 years old, with five children and live in polygamous families in Sanoubougou I, one of several populous neighbourhoods in Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is their first collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, with the purpose of satisfying their customers’ needs. They run different businesses, among which the sale of food condiments, atiécké (cassava-based food preparation), and clothing fabrics (as with Mariam Cissé). With her portion of the loan Mariam Cissé will buy 20 bolts of cloth. She gets her supplies from the main market in Sikasso and from Burkina Faso, a country adjacent to Mali. She resells in the various markets of Sikasso and in the neighbourhoods, to a customer base of both men and women, and generally for cash. Whereas Mariam expects her average monthly earnings to reach 17,000 FCFA, the other group members are hoping for 12,500 FCFA, of which part will be put into savings and the remainder invested in the commercial activities. The women in the Champion group have the ambition to increase customer satisfaction and consequently their turnover.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing fabric

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida is 29-year-old woman who resides in a city named Lahore, in Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and its Punjabi foods.
 
Zubaida is a very hardworking lady. She operates a seasonal vegetable-selling business. She sells the vegetables to her neighbors from a four-wheeled cart at the entrance of her house. Her husband, whose name is Z., also helps her in her business. He goes to vegetable markets and purchases the seasonal vegetables for her business. She has been in this profession for over eight years. 

Zubaida is the mother of five children, two sons and three daughters. She has enrolled all of her children in school because she wants them to have a good education so they can improve their future and make themselves proud.  

Zubaida has successfully repaid three loans to Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a fourth loan to purchase vegetables to expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase seasonal vegetables to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: sell fish, food condiments and palm oil.

loans.name: Bilquis' Group

texts.en:
Bilquis is the wife of G. M. and resides in a city named Lahore in Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and its Punjabi foods
 
She is 44 years old but she is a very active lady. She performs the duties of a seamstress in her community. She has been doing this work for over five years and earns approximately $36 every month.
 
Bilquis has two children, one son and one daughter. Her son is 22 years old and works in a local factory for a monthly wage, and her daughter is 15 years old and stays at home where she manages the domestic chores. Her husband is an electrician who runs an electric shop in the community where he sells  electrical supplies such as wires, tube lights and bulbs. He has been running this shop for the last twenty-six years.  

Bilquis has repaid her first loan to Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy electrical supplies to expand her husband’s business.

loans.use: Purchase electrical supplies to sell

loans.name: Finesse. Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Finesse sont des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 32ans et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de condiments, d’atiecké tels Sanata Diabaté, de la restauration et de tissus.
Quant à l’utilisation du prêt, Sanata Diabaté compte utiliser le sien pour acheter, 2sacs de 100kg d’atiecké au grand  marché de Sikasso ville et effectue sa vente dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant. 
 Tout comme les autres membres du groupe, Sanata envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 13.250FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four members of the Finesse group are married women, and are on average 32 years old with four children. Most of them live in polygamous families in Sanoubougou I, one of several populous neighbourhoods in Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is their first collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, with the purpose of satisfying their customers’ needs. They have different businesses, among which preparing meals for sale or selling clothing fabric, food condiments, or (as in the case of Sanata Diabaté) atiécké, a cassava-based foodstuff. With regard to the loan use, Sanata Diabaté will use her portion to buy two 100-kilo bags of atiécké at the main market in Sikasso. She will then resell it in the various markets of Sikasso and in the neighbourhoods, to a customer base of both men and women, and generally for cash. Like the other group members, Sanata expects an average monthly income of 13,250 FCFA, from which part will be put into savings and the remainder invested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy atiécké

loans.name: Staila's Group

texts.en:
Staila is 40 years old and married with five children: four sons and one daughter. Her elder son is an electrician and also sells electrical supplies in the community. The others are free and don’t do anything.
 
Staila has a very friendly nature. She makes photo frames on order and generates a good income. She utilizes her income to pay for the utilities. Her husband is a janitor in a Government school. Their earnings help them to manage the financial needs of their family.

Staila has successfully repaid two loans to Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a third loan to purchase electrical supplies (wires, tube lights and bulbs) to expand her son's business. 

They all live in a city named Lahore in Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and its Punjabi foods.

loans.use: Purchase electrical supplies for her son to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stocking and selling cassava flour

loans.name: Kotognogontala. Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Kotognogontala sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 37ans, 2 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et  tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de condiments alimentaires, de boissons non alcoolisées, d’huile de palme, de bois de chauffe, de  mercerie et de volailles.
Absetou F., qui est un des membres du groupe s’est spécialisée dans la préparation de jus de fruits et la vente de boissons non alcoolisées.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, Absetou F. compte acheter, 20 casiers de boissons non alcoolisées auprès des dépositaires agrées de la place à Sikasso. Elle  vend en détail au comptant rarement à crédit, dans les différents quartiers de la ville à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle espère réaliser  comme les autres membres, un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 13.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisé en épargne et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Kotognogontala group are married women who average 37 years of age with two children; the majority of them live in polygamous families in Sanoubougou 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are on their fifth loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, which they are taking out to satisfy the needs of their customers; all their previous loans have been repaid on time. They have a variety of activities which include among others the sale of food condiments, non-alcoholic drinks, palm oil, firewood, haberdashery products and poultry. Absetou F., who is one of the group members, is specialised in the preparation of fruit juices and the sale of non-alcoholic drinks. With this new loan, Absetou F. is planning on buying 20 crates of non-alcoholic drinks from local authorised depositories in Sikasso. She sells on a retail basis for cash and rarely on credit, in various districts of the town, to a customer base made up of men and women. In common with the other group members, she hopes to make an average monthly profit of 13,500FCFA, of which part will be saved and the rest invested in the business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of non-alcoholic drinks

loans.name: Lubowa B Magoba Phibe Group

texts.en: M. Phibe is a 22-year-old hardworking business lady and she is single with no children. She has stayed in business for over two years. She is using the loan to purchase two thousand chicks to raise, both layers and broilers. She is looking forward to prospering.

loans.use: To purchase two thousand chicks.

loans.name: Soutoura. Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Soutoura sont des femmes mariées  ayant en moyenne 37ans, 2 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et tous les prêts passés se sont  bien dénoués. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente condiments,  de produits cosmétiques tels Wassa C., de fruits et légumes, de bois de chauffe, de vêtements pour  enfants et divers autres produits alimentaires et ménagers. 
S’agissant de l’utilisation de ce nouveau prêt, Wassa C. compte utiliser le sien pour acheter, 3 colis de produits cosmétiques de différentes sortes. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente au comptant en détail rarement à crédit, dans les différents quartiers à une clientèle composée essentiellement  de femmes. 
 Les membres du groupe Soutoura envisagent réaliser chacun un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The six members of the Soutoura group are married women, who average 37 years of age and have two children; the majority live in polygamous families in Sanoubougou 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are on their fifth loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, which they have taken out to satisfy the needs of their customers; all their previous loans have been repaid correctly. They have a variety of activities which include, among others, the sale of condiments, cosmetic products in the case of Wassa Couibaly for instance, fruit and vegetables, firewood, children's clothes and other diverse food and household products. As far as this new loan is concerned, Wassa C. is planning to use hers to buy three parcels of different types of cosmetic products.
