She gets her supplies from wholesalers at the big market in Sikasso Town and sells them for cash and on a retail basis, but rarely on credit, in the different districts of the town, to a customer base made up principally of women. The members of the Soutoura group envisage making an average monthly profit of 15,000FCFA each, of which part will be saved and the rest invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetic products

loans.name: Confiance ["confidence"] Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Confiance (6 femmes mariées  et 1 célibataire) ont une moyenne d’âge de 39ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des familles monogames à Ouayerma I, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur dixième  prêt solidaire et tous les neufs précédents ont  été bien remboursés. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente des condiments alimentaires, de  gingembre, de  bois de chauffe,  de pomme de terre, de savons et  de chaussures. 
Kadi S. qui la présidente du groupe fait l’achat et la vente de condiments. Elle est très sollicitée et appréciée à Sikasso où elle reçoit beaucoup de clients.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter,   des paquets de condiments alimentaires de différentes sortes et qualités. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les localités avoisinantes. Les marchandises sont vendues, la plupart au comptant, dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
 Les membres du groupe Confiance envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 13.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Confiance [“Confidence”] group, six married women and one single woman, average 39 years of age and three children and live in monogamous families in Ouayerma I, a district in the town of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better satisfy their customers’ needs. This would be their tenth joint loan, with the previous nine loans having been duly reimbursed. They are engaged in various business activities, such as selling food condiments, ginger, heating wood, potatoes, soaps and shoes. Kadi S., the group’s leader, buys and resells condiments. Her business is well-known and popular in Sikasso, where she has a lot of customers. With this new loan she plans to purchase packs of condiments of various types and quality grades. She buys her stock at the big market of Sikasso and in nearby villages. Her goods are sold mostly for cash at the different markets in Sikasso as well as in residential areas, to a customer base composed of both women and men. The members of the Confiance group anticipate obtaining a monthly income of 13,500 West African francs for each member, a part of which will be put aside as savings and the rest reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing food condiments (for resale)

loans.name: Djénèba

texts.fr:
Djénèba N. est une veuve de 57 ans, mère de douze enfants, qui vit avec 7 de ses enfants chez son défunt époux à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative du Mali).
Djénèba N. mène cette activité d’achat et de vente de charbon de bois il y a environ 10 ans. Elle jouit d’une forte réputation dans cette activité et reçoit beaucoup de commandes surtout en saison hivernale.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, elle sollicita la collaboration de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel après 5 prêts solidaires. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Djénèba compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des chargements de charrettes en sacs de charbon de bois auprès des producteurs dans les localités environnantes de la ville de Sikasso. Elle vend  devant son domicile, en gros et détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée  de revendeurs et de consommateurs.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 100.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour régler l’essentielle de ses dépenses, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Djénèba N. is a 57-year old widow and the mother of 12 children. She lives with seven of her children in the house of her late husband in Wayerma I, a modest district in the town of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). She has been engaged in buying and reselling charcoal for about 10 years. She has a good business reputation and receives a lot of orders, especially in the winter season. In her search for additional financial resources, she has started collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso, and this would be her second individual loan after five joint loans. All previous loans have been duly repaid. Djénèba plans to use this loan to buy cartloads of charcoals in bags from the local producers in the villages surrounding Sikasso. She sells in front of her house, wholesale and retail, for cash and n credit, to a customer base composed of both women and men. With this new loan, she anticipates obtaining a monthly income of 100,000 West African francs, which will be used to cover the most essential expenditures, contribute to the family budget, pay off the interest on her loan and reinvest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing charcoal (for resale)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling food products

loans.name: Yacouba

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Yacouba Traoré  a 33 ans, marié et père de six enfants. Il réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Bougoula Hameau situé environ à 7km de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Yacouba Traoré, après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié au commerce d’articles divers de boutique. Il dispose d’une boutique devant son domicile où il mène cette activité d’achat et vente des articles divers  tels le maïs,  les Cigarettes, les bonbons,  les allumettes,  les Cheewing Gum, du lait en poudre,  du Thé, du  sucre, des  savons, etc  il y a environ douze 12 ans. 
Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant trois  ans. 
Après  avoir correctement remboursés les deux prêts précédents, il est à son troisième prêt qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 4 tonnes de maïs, 12 cartouches de Cigarettes différentes, 2 carton du thé, 4 sacs du sucre, 12 paquets de lait en poudre, 5 paquets de bonbon, 10 paquet de Chewing Gum, 30 paquets d’allumette, 5 cartons de savons.
 Il s’approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes de la ville avant de les revendre en détail, au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée de toute la couches sociale de sa localité.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Yacouba Troré is 33 yars of age, married and the father of six children. He lives with his wife and children in an extend traditional family in the village of Bougoula, about 7 km (4 miles) from the town of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). Mr. Yacouba Traoré, after trying different business activities without success, launched a general store. He keeps a small store in front of his house, where he sells diverse articles such as cornmeal, cigarettes, candy, matches, chewing gum, powdered milk, tea, sugar, soaps etc. He has been doing for about 12 years. His business is very popular with the customers due to the quality of his goods. In order to satisfy the ever growing demand, three years ago he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After having duly repaid his previous two loans, he is now on his third loan, which will be used to purchase 4 tons of cornmeal, 12 cartons of different kinds of cigarettes, 2 cartons of tea, 4 bags of sugar, 12 packs of powdered milk, 5 packs of candy, 10 packs of chewing gum, 30 packs of matches, and 5 cartons of soap. He purchases his stock from wholesale retailers in town and sells retail, for cash or on credit, to a customer base representing all social layers of his neighborhood. With this loan, he anticipates achieving a monthly income of 250,000 West African Francs, which will be used essentially to bolster his business capital, contribute to the family budget, pay off the interest on his loan and reinvest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing various articles (for resale)

loans.name: Yaya

texts.fr:
Monsieur Yaya C. est marié à une femme et n’a pas d’enfant. Il est né à Nantanso vers 1986  dans la préfecture de Sikasso, (3eme région administrative du Mali).  Il vit à Loulouni dans une famille traditionnelle élargie.
Il fait le commerce d’articles divers  depuis 5 ans et de plus en plus il commence à se spécialiser dans l’achat et la vente de tasses et ustensiles de cuisine en plastique. 
Il mène son commerce avec assez de réussite compte tenu de son expérience à la matière.
Il est à sa première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Il compte acheter avec son prêt , 5 dizaines de seaux , 3 douzaines de baignoires  et 10 douzaines assiettes  +  des louches  tous en plastique.
Il vend en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes .  
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.000 FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car il  ambitionne  construire  sa propre maison à usage d’habitation à Loulouni ville.
texts.en:
Mr. Yaya C. is married to a woman and doesn't have any children. He was born in Nantanso around 1986 in the prefecture of Sikasso (Mali's 3rd administrative district). He lives in Loulouni in an extended traditional family. He has been selling assorted goods for five years and is beginning more and more to specialize in the purchase and sale of plastic cups and kitchenware. Mr. C. conducts his business fairly successfully, considering his experience in the matter. He is in his first collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. With his loan, Mr. C. plans to buy 50 buckets, 3 dozen tubs and 10 dozen plates, plus ladles, all plastic. He sells retail and in cash to a customer base of women and men. Mr. C. plans to realize an average monthly profit of 30,000 CFA francs per month, of which part will be used to expand the business and the other part will be put in savings, as he aspires to build his own house in which to live in Loulouni.

Translated from French by Jessalyn Pinneo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying plastic cups and kitchenware.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Making and selling cassava flour

loans.name: Assétou

texts.fr:
Assétou Koné a  47 ans mariée et mère de trois enfants (1 garçon et 2 filles). Elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Assétou Koné,  après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à  l’activité d’achat de stockage et commercialisation des céréales (maïs, mil, sorgho, arachide, riz, fonio, etc) il y a environ quatre ans. Elle dispose d’un magasin au grand marché de Sikasso où elle exerce son activité. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.  Après 6 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association Benkadi de Sanoubougou II), elle est actuellement à son troisième prêt individuel. Tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 8 sacs de riz, 7 sacs de sorgho, 10 sacs de maïs, 5 sacs d’arachide et 4 sacs de mil. 
Elle achète le riz à Niono (région de Ségou) et les autres céréales dans les localités environnantes de Sikasso avant de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée généralement de consommateurs.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 275 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Assétou Koné is 47 years old, married, and the mother of three children (one boy and two girls).  She resides with her husband and their children in Sanoubougou II, one of the working-class districts of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having run several businesses without success, she was introduced to the business of stocking up and marketing of grains (corn, millet, sorghum, peanuts, rice, fonio, etc.) about four years ago.  She has a store at the big market of Sikasso were she operates this business. Concerned about further satisfying her customer base, which is growing more and more, Assétou decided to joint the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After six solidarity loans (group loans) in a women's association in her district (Association Benkadi de Sanoubougou II), she is currently on her third individual loan.  The preceding loans have all been properly repaid.  Assétou intends to use this loan for buying eight sacks of rice, seven sacks of sorghum, ten of corn, five of peanuts, and four of millet.  She buys the rice in Niono (Ségou region); the other grains, from towns around Sikasso.  Then she sells the grains retail to a customer base composed generally of consumers.  With this loan, Assétou envisions making a monthly profit of 275,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially for increasing her capital, taking part in meeting family expenses, paying the loan interest, and investing the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Ayoko Akpédjé

texts.fr: Cette jeune femme est très dynamique, elle n’a pas fait de longue étude, afin de subvenir à ses besoins elle s’est lancée il y a deux ans de cela dans le commerce de détail des télévisions, amplificateur, portables, radio et autres. Elle a déjà obtenu du crédit de WAGES qu’elle a bien remboursé, voulant augmenter son stock, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de baffles, télévision à écran plasma, portables et divers.
texts.en:
This young woman is very dynamic. She was not in school for long. In order to provide for her needs, two years ago, she launched herself in the retail business selling televisions, amplifiers, mobile phones, radios and more. She has already received a loan from WAGES that she fully reimbursed. Wanting to increase her stock, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase speakers, plasma screen TVs, mobile phones and various goods.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of electronic equipment

loans.name: Aminatou

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité la vente de produits d’alimentation générale, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2008 dans le marché local d’agoè atsanvé , elle a une grande clientèle composée de personnes de tout âge qui grandit chaque jour. Pour les satisfaire tous, elle doit gonfler son stock raison pour laquelle elle souhaite obtenir de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de divers produits d’alimentation générale.
texts.en:
This woman’s activity is the sales of general food products. She has been in this business in the local market of Agoè Atsanvé since 2008. She has a customer base that increases every day. To meet all of their demands, she must increase her stock. This is the reason why she wishes to receive a loan from WAGES, to purchase various general food products.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of general food products.

loans.name: Ameer's Group

texts.en:
Ameer is the wife of G. S. and resides in a city named Multan in Pakistan. Multan city is famous for its shrines and sweetmeats. 

She is 54 years old and operates her own sewing business. She learned this art from her mother and started sewing after her marriage. She has steadily increased her business, and now she is going to start her own boutique where she will display her handmade dresses. 

Ameer is the mother of three sons. Her first two sons work in a tailoring shop for monthly wages. The youngest of them reads in 7th standard. 

Ameer has successfully repaid two loans to Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to purchase supplies in bulk, like beads, colored thread and fabric, to make dresses for her boutique.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for making dresses

loans.name: Abdou Fatawou

texts.fr:
En 2008, ce monsieur a ouvert sa propre boutique de vente de produits d’alimentation générale qu’il a appelé « ETS BAS PRIX », il s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé, 3 personnes de sa famille l’aident dans la gestion de son commerce. En ce moment, son stock est en baisse, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit  pour l’achat d’huile, de tomates en bois, de lait concentré et divers autres produits d’alimentation générale pour renforcer son stock.
Etant célibataire il subvient à ses besoins grâce aux revenus de son commerce.
texts.en:
In 2008, this gentleman opened his own shop selling general food products. He called his store “ETS BAS PRIX” [Est. Low Prices]. He gets his supplies from the grand market in Lomé. Three members of his family help him to manage his business. At this time his stock is diminishing. He is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase oil, canned tomatoes, condensed milk and various other general food products to replenish his stock. Being single, he provides for his needs thanks to the income from his business.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of general food products.

loans.name: Bendiya Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Bendiya sont mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles ayant en moyenne 37 ans, 4 enfants et habitant  toutes, Farabougou, un  village de la Commune Rurale de Téssérèla  (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, de voisinage et de leurs activités commerciales.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de condiments alimentaires tels l’oignon avec Awa C., les friandises, les céréales, les calebasses etc.
Dans le souci d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, elles décidèrent de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso, et sont  à son  tout 1er  prêt solidaire.
Awa C. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 300kg d’oignon frais. Elle s’approvisionne à N’gassola et à Tissala. Elle revend son oignon frais à domicile et à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou généralement au comptant. 
Madame Awa compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 17.000FCFA qui servira au remboursement  son prêt, à la contribution pour la prise en charge de certaines dépenses familiales et à la participation aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes et funérailles).
texts.en:
The ten members of the group Bendiya are married women mostly in large traditional families.  The members average 37 years of age and four children each, and they all live in Farabougou, a village of the rural community of Téssérèla (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through ties of kinship, marriage, and community, and through their businesses.  This group of women does commerce in condiments, such as onions (with Ms. Awa C.), sweets, grains, calabashes, etc. Wanting to increase their working capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their very first solidarity loan.  Awa C. intends to use her loan for buying 200 kg of fresh onions.  She stocks up in N’gassola and in Tissala.  Generally accepting cash, she resells her fresh onions out of her home and at the weekly fair in Ségou,   Awa plans on making a monthly profit of 17,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay her loan, to take part in covering certain family expenses, and participating in societal events (marriages, baptisms, and funerals.)

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fresh onions

loans.name: Atsu

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un responsable de famille, il a 2 enfants et sa femme est une coiffeuse. Il y a 5 ans il a ouvert une boutique qu’il a appelé « ETS VIACO » dans laquelle il faisait le commerce de pièces détachées Avec le revenu de ce commerce il subvient aux charges de sa famille. Il a reçu de ses clients des commandes qu’il ne peut satisfaire avec son stock actuel, il sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de pièces détachées de véhicules et de motos. Il s’approvisionne au burkina faso
texts.en:
This gentleman is the head of a household; he has two children, and his wife is a hairdresser. Five years ago he opened a shop that he calls « ETS VIACO », where he does business selling spare parts. With the income from this business, he is able to pay his family's expenses. He has received orders from his clients that he can't fill from his current stock. Thus he is seeking a loan through WAGES for the purchase of automobile and motorcycle parts. He gets his supplies in Burkina Faso.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of spare parts

loans.name: Nighat's Group

texts.en:
Nighat is a very talented and hardworking lady. She embroiders dresses and sells them in boutiques. Her work attracts more customers so the owners of boutiques come to her with orders. She earns approximately $60 a month, which is a big source of income for the family. 

She has six children: three sons and three daughters. All of her kids are enrolled in school. 

Her husband operates a wood-selling business in the community. He also goes to different areas on his donkey cart to deliver his customers' orders. He has been in this business for over ten years. 

Nighat is applying for the first time for a loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan) to purchase embroidery items in bulk (beads, colored threads, sketches and fabric) to expand her embroidery business.

loans.use: Purchase items for making embroidered dresses

loans.name: Amélé

texts.fr: Cette dame est une femme mariée avec 4 enfants, son mari est un chauffeur. En 2001, elle a commencé le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, elle s’approvisionne à Lomé. Son dynamisme et son expérience dans ce travail fait qu’elle en a une parfaite maîtrise. Elle fait face en ce moment à une baisse constante de son stock de marchandises et ce à cause de sa clientèle qui ne cesse de grandir. Elle veut augmenter son stock raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 5 cartons de spaghetti, 4 sacs de riz, 3 boîtes de conserve et divers autres produits d’alimentation générale
texts.en:
This woman is married and has four children; her husband is a driver. In 2001, she began selling basic grocery items. She gets her supplies in Lomé. Her enthusiasm and experience makes her an expert in this business. She is currently facing the continual reduction of her merchandise stock, because her clientele never ceases to grow. She wants to increase her stock; this is why she is seeking a loan through WAGES, in order to buy five cartons of spaghetti, four bags of rice, three boxes of canned goods, and various other grocery items.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of grocery items

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont mariés majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles ont en moyenne 37 ans, 5 enfants et habitent  toutes  à Farabougou, village de la Commune Rurale de Téssérèla  (4ème Région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et mariage.
Ce groupe  qui est à son premier prêt solidaire, fait le commerce d’articles divers avec les condiments alimentaires, le poisson séché, le gombo, les feuilles de fakoye, des céréales, su Sounbala, etc. 
 Madame Nièdiogou  Sangaré qui  est un des membres du groupe Benkadi, est  bien connue dans la zone grâce à sa spécialisation de séchage du poisson frais.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt  pour acheter, 50 kg de poisson frais au bord du fleuve Bani avec les pêcheurs. Le poisson est d’abord séché dans un coin de la cours avec un séchoir conçu traditionnellement pour la circonstance pendant au moins une semaine. Nièdiogou à l’instar des autres membres du groupe revend sa marchandise à domicile, dans les foires de Gassola, Tissala et Téssérèla au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle mixte. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser le prêt et contribuer à  certaines dépenses familiales. 
Elles ont pour ambition l’achat d’une charrette et d’un âne pour assurer leur transport et celui des marchandises dans les différentes foires.
texts.en:
The members of the group Benkadi are generally married in large, traditional extended families. They are on average 37 years old with five children, all living in Farabougou, a village in the Rural Community of Téssérèla (4th administrative region of Mali). They are acquainted through family ties and through marriage. The group, which is on its first group loan, does business selling various products such as condiments, dried fish, okra, fakoye (wild leaf used as seasoning), grains, sounbala (condiment made from seeds of the néré tree), etc. Mrs. Nièdiogou Sangaré, one of the members of the Benkadi group, is well-known in the area, thanks to her specialization in dried fish. She plans to use her loan to buy fifty kilograms of fresh fish from those who fish on the banks of the Bani River. The fish is first dried in a corner of the courtyard for a week on a drying rack designed traditionally for the purpose. Nièdiogou, like other members of the group, resells her products from home and in the markets of Gassola, Tissala, and Téssérèla, for cash and on credit to both men and women. They hope to make an average monthly profit of 20,000 FCFA, which will be used to reimburse the loan and contribute to certain family expenses. Their ambition is to buy a cart and a donkey to transport them and their wares to various markets.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fresh fish

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad is the wife of A. D. and lives in a city named Multan in Pakistan. Multan city is famous for its shrines and sweetmeats.
 
She is a very active and caring lady. She stays at home and takes care of her family and does the domestic chores. She has five kids: two sons and three daughters. Her elder son is a carpenter and makes furniture on order to generate income. The others are enrolled in school and are getting an education. 

Her husband has been operating a wood-selling business for the last five years. He has a good number of customers and receives many orders. Irshad has applied for a loan to buy wood in bulk because the currently available wood is insufficient for filling the orders. Buying in bulk will allow him to complete the orders on time, which helps his customers and makes a profit.

loans.use: Purchase wood in bulk to complete orders

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tièssiri comprend dix membres,  toutes mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont moyenne 37 ans, 4 enfants et  habitent  toutes  à Farabougou, un village de la Commune Rurale de Téssérèla  (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, mariage, de voisinage et de leurs activités commerciales.
Ce groupe Tièssiri qui est à son premier prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso et fait l’achat et la vente des céréales tels Mariam C. qui a choisi comme créneau l’arachide.
C’est dans le souci de  diversifier et de satisfaire leurs clientèles que les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec l’institution.
Mariam compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 3 sacs d’arachide en gousse. Elle s’approvisionne à N’gassola et à Tissala. 
Selon les différentes variétés d’arachide, elle décortique le «tiga djèni » qu’elle trie avant sa vente au détail, une partie de l’arachide en gousse « tiga ba » est grillée et ou bouillie puis séchée selon les demandes des clients.  
Elle revend son  arachide à domicile, en ambulant à travers le village par ses enfants et quelques rares fois à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme, de femme et d’enfant.  
Mariam espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de19.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser son prêt, contribuer à  certaines dépenses familiales, participer aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes et funérailles), augmenter son fonds de commerce et à l’achat de quelques ustensiles de cuisine pour préparer le trousseau de mariage des jeunes filles.
texts.en:
The Tièssiri group comprises ten members, for the most part married into traditional extended families. They are on average 37 years old with four children, and all live in Farabougou, a village in the Téssérèla Rural Community (4th administrative region of Mali). They became acquainted through family ties, marriage, as neighbours and through their commercial activities. The Tièssiri group is requesting its first group loan with Soro Yiriwaso, and focuses on trading cereals, like Mariam C., who chose the peanut market niche. The group members decided to collaborate with the institution with the aim to diversify and satisfy their customers. Mariam will use her portion of the loan to buy three bags of unshelled peanuts, which she purchases in N’gassola and Tissala. The process depends on the variety of peanut: she shells and sorts the “tiga djèni” before selling them retail, whereas part of the unshelled “tiga ba” is grilled or boiled, then dried according to the customer’s requests. She resells her peanuts from her home, throughout the village with help from her children, and on rare occasions at the weekly market fair in Segou, for cash or credit, to men, women and children customers. Mariam hopes to achieve monthly earnings of 19,000 FCFA which will be used to reimburse her loan, contribute to some family expenses, participate in social festivities (weddings, baptisms, and funerals), increase her working capital, and purchase a few kitchen utensils in view of preparing the young girls’ wedding dowries.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy peanuts

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more oil, peppers, potatoes and other vegetables.

loans.name: Allah Diwae's Group

texts.en:
Allah diwae is the wife of M. M. and they have lived for the last ten years in a two-room brick house in a city named Multan (famous for its shrines and sweetmeats) in Pakistan. 

She is 54 years old but she is still very active and operates her decorative embroidery business. Her family supports her in her business. They all prepare the embroidered dresses and complete the orders of the customers, which generates income. 

She became the breadwinner of her family after the death of her husband. She is a regular client of Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). She has repaid her two loans to Asasah and now has applied for the third time to purchase the supplies she needs (colored thread, beads and fabrics) to expand her decorative embroidery business.

loans.use: Purchase embroidery items for preparing embroidered dresses

loans.name: Adella

texts.en: Adella is a married mother of two children and her children go to school. She rents a two-room house where she stays with five people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Adella takes care of additional family members (her sister). Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. Adella operates a retail shop in Kamwokya Kifumbira where she sells all merchandise like  sugar salt maize flour rice and many others and sells to all categories of people on retail. She works seven days a week. Adella receives at least 25 customers a day she has been in this business for nine years and her business challenges include seasonality and defaulters.  Besides this retail shop business she also owns a motorcycle which brings in 8000/= daily.  She has been with MCDT for many years servicing her 21st loan. Her major customers are neighbors and school children.> She wants to use this loan  to buy more bags of sugar and rice , cartons of salt, maize flour and cooking oil. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger, start selling at wholesale only and owning her own house.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar , rice,  maize flour ,cartons of salt and cooking oil

loans.name: One Word 2 Group

texts.en:
Theresa S. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called One Word 2. She is 42 years old, married, and has four children aged between 12 and 20 years old. She also cares for two nieces. She was fortunate enough to attend a teacher’s college.
For 15 years, Theresa has been producing and selling soaps and palm oil at Blama Cee Town Road in Brewerville, Liberia. Her father gave her two tins of oil to start her business. She attracts customers by producing clean, good soap, and approaching them in a good manner. Her goal is to grow her business to a shop, educate her children, and build a house for her family.
Theresa plans to use her 10,000 LRD portion of the group loan of 50,000 LRD to buy used clothes, palm oil and caustic soda to produce soap. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Theresa is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.
Join the Team LEAP – Liberia lending team on Kiva today at http://www.kiva.org/team/team_leap_liberia

loans.use: To buy used clothes, palm oil and caustic soda to produce soap.

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz is a wife of M. S. and lives in the city of Multan, Pakistan, famous for its shrines and sweetmeats. She is an enthusiastic lady who stays at home to manage the household work, but also runs her own business sewing clothes for her neighbors in order to generate income.
Shahnaz is a mother of five children – one son and four daughters. All of her children are receiving an education from the local school. Her husband has an animal-selling business. He purchases animals from the animal markets and sells them on to customers. His customer base is mostly butchers in need of good animals who approach him because he has good knowledge of animal breeds. He has 25 years of experience in this business. Currently, the family has one cow at their home.
Shahnaz has successfully repaid her first loan to Kiva partner, Asasah (a microfinance institution in Pakistan). Now she has applied for a new loan to buy animals (a cow and goats) to expand her husband’s animal-selling business.

loans.use: To purchase animals to resell

loans.name: Massajja B Nabaale Mariam Group

texts.en: N. Mariam is 27 years old, married, and has three children in school. She is a businesswoman who has been selling children's clothes for one year. She is using her loan to purchase stock to sell to her customers. Mariam wants to improve her business, and her dream is to work very hard for the welfare of her family.

loans.use: To purchase clothing stock

loans.name: Osman Sillah

texts.en: Osman S. K. is a devoted and hardworking trader. He has a small shop, at the centre of the township of Makeni, where he sells food items and phone accessories. Over the years, his business has been doing well but operating on a very small scale because his capital is small. Osman's desire is to obtain more capital to plough into the business, which will enable him to buy more stock for his shop. As a result, he is in great need of a loan to help him achieve his dream. Osman also hopes to use the proceeds from his loan to support his family and other relatives.

loans.use: To buy phone accessories

loans.name: Massajja B Babirye Mwesige Group

texts.en: Babirye M. is 38 years old, married, and has seven children, five of whom are in school. She has been running a clothes boutique for over 15 years. She is using her loan to purchase more new clothing stock for resale. Babirye is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to prosper in life.

loans.use: To purchase new clothing stock for resale

loans.name: Massajja C Kakembo Mariam Group

texts.en: K. Mariam is 45 years old, widowed, and a mother of five children. She has been running a charcoal business for over ten years. She is using her loan to purchase charcoal from villages to sell in town. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal from villages to sell in town

loans.name: Flourish Business Partners Group

texts.en:
Flourish Business Partners is a group of five borrowers headed by Patrick B.. Patrick is 39 years old and a high school graduate. He is single and has four children aged from 12 to 20 years old. All of his children attend school, with the youngest in elementary school, and the eldest in junior high.  He also helps take care of two siblings.
Patrick has been running a tailoring business for ten years. His business is located at the Paynesville Red Light Market. He started his business with 7,000 LRD and now has 20,000 LRD as working capital. He faces challenge from many other competitors in the same business. 
Patrick says that his sales are booming due to his good manner of approach and his smiling face. His hope is for his business to grow into a large shop, and he plans to use his 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to purchase more cloth, thread and other tailoring materials. His dream is to be healthy and live a good and happy life.
In the photo that accompanies this profile, Patrick is holding the sign.

About LEAP
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.
Join the Team LEAP – Liberia lending team on Kiva today by visiting http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To purchase more cloth, thread and other tailoring materials

loans.name: God Grace Group

texts.en:
God Grace Group is a group of five borrowers, headed by Josephine W.. She is 42 years old and she could not continue her education through high school due to the Liberian Civil crisis. She’s married, and has five children whose ages range from 10 to 24 years old.  All of her children attend school, with the youngest in elementary school, while the oldest is a high school graduate. She also helps to care for one sibling.

Josephine’s business activity is the sale of used clothes, and she has been doing this business for ten years. She started her business with 1,000 Liberian dollars and now has 22,000 Liberian dollars as working capital. Her business is located on Front Street, in downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

She says her sales are booming due to the availability of first class materials. Her hope is for her business to grow and transform into a building materials store. She plans to use her 16,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 80,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase more first class used clothes.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Josephine Warner is holding the sign.


About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia 's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.  

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To purchase more first class used clothes for resale

loans.name: Kadzo Katana

texts.en:
Kadzo is 23 years old and married to Changawa, a taxi driver. Together they have four children whose ages are between 10 years old and 3 years old. Kadzo is in the business of selling vegetables and fruit in the Kibokoni area of Malindi, where her targets customers are the locals. She has been in business for the past two years, and she earns a monthly profit of Kshs 6,500. 

Kadzo was introduced to Kadet by an existing client and this is her first loan. With this loan, she will renovate the food stand with Kshs 3,000, restock vegetables and fruit with Kshs 3,000, and diversify to another business of selling clothes with Kshs 5,000. She hopes to earn a profit to use as savings, and invest more in her children’s education.

Kadzo is a hardworking woman, and in the future, she hopes to own a Nissan matatu, which she will use in the transport business, thus boosting her income.

loans.use: Renovate food stand, stock vegetables and fruit, and open up another business of selling clothes

loans.name: Vincent Nguma

texts.en:
Vincent is 35 years old and married to Dama; together they have six children. 

Vincent is a farmer in Kibaoni, Malindi, and he has been farming for the past three years. He normally gets a monthly profit of Kshs 5,700. 

Vincent was introduced to Kadet by an existing member of his current group. He has applied for a loan which he will use Kshs 5,000 for land preparation, Kshs 4,000 to buy seedlings for cassava, Kale (locally known as sukuma wiki) and tomatoes, Kshs 10,000 to buy fertilizers and Kshs 1,000 on miscellaneous expenses. With the extra earnings from this loan he will buy a plot and pay school fees for his children. 

Vincent is a  hardworking man who hopes to venture into the hotel business in the future.

loans.use: Land preparation and to buy seedlings and fertilizers

loans.name: Rehema Kashuru

texts.en:
Rehema is 24 years old and single; she resides in Kibaoni-Malindi. She is a tailor by profession and use of this training has been her main source of income. She normally makes designs and sews clothes for a fee and this earns her a monthly profit of Kshs 4,000. Her customers are mainly parents with school going children in the area. 

Rehema was introduced to Kadet by an existing member and this is her first loan. She plans to us the payments from this loan to buy materials/fabric for school uniforms at a price of Kshs 8,000, other more stylish materials for Kshs 5,000, and to pay for transport and miscellaneous expenses with Kshs 2,000. The extra income she anticipates to get from this loan will be used to buy a plot and build her own tailoring shop and rental rooms.

Rehema hopes to see her business grow and she believes she is a hardworking woman.

loans.use: To buy fabric for school uniforms and styliish materials, and pay for transport

loans.name: Juan Antonio

texts.es:
El Señor Juan Antonio es oriundo de la ciudad de Ybycui, vive en el Bº Santa Rosa de la misma ciudad, empezó en el negocio de la zapatería desde el año 1999.
         Con el correr de los años la producción de su negocio no fue del nada bueno, por esa razón sus hijos tuvieron que emigrar a otro pais con el fin de enviar ayuda económica, después de un tiempo pudo acceder a comprar una vaca lechera con la cual empezó a vender leche a vecinos, después compró otra vaca hasta que llegó a 5, la cantidad de vacunos con los que cuenta ahora gracias a la ayuda de sus hijos y con eso ya le provee de leche a todo el barrio donde vive.
         Al mismo tiempo trabajaba con su zapatería y con el correr del tiempo empezó a producir más, solicitó un préstamo a nuestra institución, para compra de materiales para la confección de calzados para estudiantes ya que en estas fechas es la temporada en la que más salida tiene ésta mercadería.
         Agradece a La Fundación Paraguaya y KIVA por su apoyo y por seguir confiando en él.
texts.en:
Mr. Juan Antonio is from the city of Ybycui, where he lives in Bº Santa Rosa. He started his shoe business in 1999. Over the years, the productivity of his business was not going well, so his children had to emigrate to another country, with the goal of sending money back. After some time, he agreed to buy a dairy cow, and he began to sell milk to his neighbors. Later, he bought another cow; he now has five cows, thanks to the help of his children. With these cows, he is able to provide milk to his entire neighborhood. At the same time, he continued to work in his shoe store, and with time, he began to produce more. He is requesting a loan from our institution to buy materials to make footwear for students, since this type of merchandise sells well at this time of the year. He is thankful to Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva for their support and for their continued confidence in him.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy leather and accessories to make shoes

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert N. is 47 years old and is married to Mary Akinyi, a business lady. 

Robert is a food vendor in the Kongowea market of Mombasa and has been in this business for past three years. He mainly sells sausages and samosas to customers within and outside of the market and is able to get a profit of between Kshs 15,000 to Kshs 20,000 every month.

Robert was introduced to KADET by a client in the group he is in and hopes to borrow subsequent loans from KADET in future. This marks Robert's first borrowing from KADET and with this money, he plans to purchase a refrigerator and raw sausages. 

Robert hopes to become a distributor of raw sausages and sell them to retailers.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator and raw sausages

loans.name: Rosa De La Cruz

texts.es:
La señora Rosa De La Cruz vive en el Bº Sta Rosa de la Ciudad de Ybycui, vive con su marido y con sus 2 hijos.
Lleva mas de 30 años en dicho negocio, empezó trabajando con su mamá, después viajó a Asunción buscando mejores oportunidades, estando allí pudo perfeccionarse estudiando Corte y Confección, después regresó por su ciudad natal para montar su propio negocio y de ahí iniciarse como modista profesional.
Actualmente se encuentra trabajando en su domicilio y ya cuenta con buena clientela quienes admiran mucho los trabajos que ella realiza. Confecciona ropas de todo tipo trajes, vestidos para novias, pantalones para damas y caballeros. 
Ella desea brindar otro servicio a su clientela montando una tienda con telas para que los clientes puedan tener la opción de elegir, para este fin solicita el préstamos y además por que recibió pedido de confección de uniformes para empleados de una fábrica de la compañía de Ybycui, y para algunos alumnos de los distintos colegios de dicha ciudad.
Agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya por la ayuda a través del préstamos y asegura luchar con muchas ganas para seguir progresando
texts.en:
Rosa De La Cruz lives in the Santa Rosa neighborhood of the city of Ybycui, along with her husband and two children. She has worked in her business for more than 30 years. She started working together with her mother, and she later went to Asunción in search of better opportunities. During her time there, she was able to advance her education by studying clothing design and creation. She later returned to her native city to start her own business as a professional clothing designer and creator. She currently works out of her home, and she has a solid base of customers who greatly admire her work. She creates clothing of all types, including suits, bridal gowns and trousers for men and women. She would like to provide an additional service to her customers: opening a fabric store to provide her clients with more choices. She is requesting the loan for this purpose, and also because she has received an order from a factory in Ybycui for employee uniforms, as well as orders for uniforms for students in some of the city's schools. Rosa is grateful to the Paraguaya Foundation for the help provided through the loan, and she assures us that she will work hard with a great desire to continue making progress.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fabrics

loans.name: Charo Masha

texts.en:
Charo is a 60-year-old farmer who lives in Malindi with his wife and ten children. Six of his children are all grown up. 

Charo has been farming for the past six years, and he normally gets a monthly profit of Kshs 6,500. He sells his harvest on wholesale terms to distributors within Malindi town. 

Charo was introduced to Kadet by an existing member of his group and is on his second loan. He has applied for a loan, with which he will use Kshs 7,500 for land preparation, Kshs 6,000 on fertilizers, Kshs 2,000 on hybrid seeds and Kshs 8,000 on labor, and he plans to save the balance for weeding. With the extra earnings from this loan, he will buy another dairy cow and save for his children’s education.

Charo is a hardworking man who hopes to build a better residential house for his family and educate children to the highest level possible.

loans.use: Land preparation, to buy fertilizers and seeds, and pay for labor

loans.name: Mariano

texts.es:
Mariano forma parte del banco comunal “LOS DIAMANTES”, tiene 50 años, es padre soltero y tiene dos hijos. El brinda servicio de transporte en un taxi, él trbaja todos los días y empieza a las 7 de la mañana  y termina a las 7 noche. Ya son 20 años que se dedica a brindar el servicio y le ha va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Mariano es una persona trabajadora y emprendedora que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos, él requiere el préstamo para la educación de sus hijos. El anhelo del socio es sacar profesional a sus hijos y comprar una casa. El banco comunal tiene 10 ciclos de funcionamiento, el socio manifiesta, que se encuentra contento y satisfecho con los servicios de crédito, ahorro y capacitación, por el tiempo de permanencia en el banco comunal. 
           
El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Mariano is a member of the Los Diamantes (The Diamonds) Community Bank. He is 50 years old, is a single father and has two children. He offers transportation services with a taxi. He works every day; his day begins at 7 in the morning and ends at 7 at night. He has been doing this for twenty years, and it has been going very well thanks to the determination that he puts into his work. Mariano is a hard-working and enterprising person, who looks at each moment as an opportunity to go forward. With daily effort, he is achieving a better future for his children. He needs a loan for his children’s education. His desire is to have his children work as professionals and to buy a house. The community bank has ten loan cycles. Mariano is happy and satisfied with the bank’s credit, savings, and training services. Mariano is thankful for this opportunity, and he promises to comply with the repayment schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Mariano needs a loan for his children's education

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en:
Aminata K. is married and has four children. She has been a trader for about 15 years now and trades in textiles, until recently when she switched to the sale of plastic shoes and slippers.

Aminata started her business with a very small amount of capital that she got from her husband. Being that she wants to expand her business by buying more goods to sell, she is in need of a loan to help her achieve her dream. It is her wish that, if successful in acquiring a loan, she will use proceeds from the loan to attend to her children's schooling needs and other domestic issues.

loans.use: To expand her business by buying more goods to sell

loans.name: Francisco Rubén

texts.es:
El  Sr. Francisco Ruben M.  es de la ciudad de San Estanislao, del Barrio Punta Suerte, tiene 59 años de edad, esta casado con la Sra. Isabel Silvera de M. de 40 años de edad, tiene 1 hijo  mayor de edad.
 
Tiene una despensa en su domicilio, con clientela formada, tiene buenos ingresos, buenas referencias comerciales y personales.
Es un señor muy trabajador, excelente cliente de la Fundación en cuanto a su responsabilidad.
El cliente esta  preparando un lugar  en su propia casa para  construir un salón   con materiales de ladrillo ya que el actual es de madera y por los años ya se encuentra   deteriorado.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de materiales de construcción y pago de mano de obra.
texts.en:
Francisco Ruben M. is from the city of San Estanislao and lives in the Punta Suerte neighborhood. He is 59 years old and married to Isabel Silvera de M., age 40. He has one grown child. He operates a convenience store in his home which has an established customer base. He has a good income and excellent business and personal references. He is a very hard-working man and an excellent and responsible client of the Foundation. Francisco is preparing a place in his home to construct a living room made out of brick. The current room is made out of wood, and it has deteriorated over the years. He is requesting the loan to buy construction materials and pay for labor.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying construction materials and paying for labor

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
God Is Able is a group of five borrowers, headed by Mary G.. She is 38 years old and did not go to school due to lack of financial support. She’s single, but has four children whose ages range from one-and-a-half years to 19 years old. All of her children attend school, with the exception of the youngest. she also to care for three siblings.

Mary sells fresh fish. She buys in bulk and sells at retail, and she has been doing this business for more than 12 years. She started her business with the help of her husband. She is challenged by delinquent customers and limited capital to get more fish for resale. Her business is located in the Waterside Market in downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

She indicated that her sales are booming due to her good manner of approach. Her hope is to improve her business, make big sales and build a house. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more fish to increase her sales.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mary G. is holding the sign. 

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia 's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

 

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy more fish to increase her sales

loans.name: Maribel Rocio

texts.es:
Maribel es socia del Banco Comunal VilL. Huatatas.
Maribel es casada, tiene 35 años y 2 hijos, Maribel se dedica a vender papa pelada y picada a las pollerias, para lo cual cuenta con 6 trabajadores, actividad que realiza todos los días. Además Maribel tiene una polleria en su casa.
Maribel necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. jabas y bolsas.
Los sueños D. Maribel son equipar su negocio y tener capital propio.
texts.en:
Maribel is a member of the VilL. Huatatas Communal Bank. She is married, 35 years old, and has two children. Maribel works every day selling peeled, chopped potatoes to the roast chicken shops, counting on the help of six workers. She also sells chickens from her house. Maribel needs a loan of 2000 soles which will be invested in the purchase of bags and containers. Her dream is to equip her business and have her own working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of bags and containers

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.es:
El  Sr. Gabriel T. J.   es de la ciudad de San Estanislao, del Barrio centro, tiene 50 años de edad, y esta casado con la Sra. Lidia Aguilar Acosta con 43 años de edad, Actualmente tienen 3 hijos, todos en edad escolar.
 
       Posee un establecimiento en la calle 8000 Bertoni, en donde se dedica a la producción y venta de leche, con clientela formada, tiene buen ingreso, buenas referencias  personales,  es un señor muy trabajador. 
 El cliente esta  preparando un lugar para construcción de un tinglado para los animales de su  tambo.

 
 Solicita un préstamo para comenzar la construcción del tinglado, como compra de  hierros, chapas.
texts.en:
Gabriel T. J. is from the downtown neighborhood of the city of San Estanislao. He is 50 years old, and is married to Lidia Aguilar Acosta, 43. They currently have 3 children; all are school-aged. He has a business on the street "8000 Bertoni" where he produces and sells milk. He has regular customers and has a good income. His personal references are good; he is a hardworking gentleman. He is preparing a place to build a shed for his dairy animals. He requests a loan to begin the construction of the shed, to pay for iron and sheet metal.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy iron rods, sheet metal, bricks, and other construction materials

loans.name: Paulina

texts.es:
Paulina es socia del Banco Comunal Villa Huatatas.
Paulina es casada, tiene 58 años y 6 hijos, Paulina tiene una panadería en su casa, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda D. 4 trabajadores. Además venD. frutas, panes en un terminal terrestre.
Paulina necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. frutas, harina y leña.
Paulina sueña con mejorar su panadería con maquinas modernas y tener capital propio.
texts.en:
Paulina is a member of the Banco Cominal Villa Huatatas.

Paulina is married, 58 years old and has 6 children. Paulina has a bakery in her home, a business which she runs everyday with the help of 4 workers. She also sells fruits and breads in the bus station.

Paulina needs a loan of 2000 soles, money which will be invested in the purchase of fruits, flour and firewood.

Paulina dreams to improve her bakery with modern machines and to have her own capital.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fruits, flour and firewood

loans.name: Sylvester

texts.en:
Sylvester S. is a 55-year-old married father of four. All his children have gotten an education with profits from his seven-year-old lucrative bar business in Kikungu, Mpigi.

It’s mostly when taxes are increased on beverages that Sylvester sees a plummet in his operations. In a week he reveals he makes more than 100,000 Ugandan shillings. His business has also benefitted from his good customer care skills.

With this loan, Sylvester wants to restock his bar business with more spirits, wines, whiskies and other beverages.

loans.use: To purchase more spirits, wines, whiskies and other beverages

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es:
Rosario es socia del Banco Comunal VilL. Huatatas.
Rosario es conviviente, tiene 33 años y 4 hijos, Rosario tiene una tienda en L. casa D. su mama en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, verduras, carnes, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Rosario necesita un préstamo D. 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. cerveza y bebidas.
Los sueños D. Rosario son ampliar su negocio, tener capital propio.
texts.en:
Rosario is a member of Banco Comunal VilL. Huatatas.

Rosario lives with her partner, is 33 years old, and has 4 children. Rosario has a store in her mother’s home where she sells general groceries, vegetables, and meats everyday.

Rosario needs a loan of 1000 soles, money which will be invested in the purchase of beer and drinks.

Rosario’s dreams are to grow her business and have her own capital.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pruchase beers and drinks

loans.name: Benina

texts.fr:
Cette femme a 45 ans, elle est très dynamique, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits génériques. Elle réalise de bonnes recettes. Son stock est en baisse, elle veut se réapprovisionner alors elle demande à WAGES son premier prêt pour acheter divers produits génériques.
Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants
texts.en:
This is a quite dynamic 45-year-old woman, who generates revenue by selling generic (no-brand) products. Her earnings are good, but her stock has decreased to the point where she needs to resupply. Therefore she is requesting her first loan from WAGES to buy various generic products. She is married and the mother of five children.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy generic products

loans.name: Cesar

texts.es:
El señor Cesar Giménez P. es de la ciudad  de Guayaybi, es soltero, vive con sus padres, tiene 27 años de edad.
     Se dedica a la venta de articulos de mercerias en general como ropas (remeras, pantalones, jeans, medias), calzados deportivos, remedios naturales, masas dulces preparados por la madre. La venta de los mismos el lo relaiza de forma ambulante recorriendo en una motocicleta que posee, el recorrido lo realiza en gran parte del 2º Departemente de San Pedro. 
El señor Cesar además de esta actividad es director propietario de una agrupación musical denominado “Los Madrigales del Ritmo” con 7 integrantes, realizan sus actuaciones por distintos lugares del 2º Departamento.
      Su sueño es contar con mas instrumentos musicales que le hace falta para asi poder brindar mejor show en cada actuación que realiza, por ello solicita el préstamo.
texts.en:
Cesar Giménez P. is from the city of Guayaybi, is single, lives with his parents, and is 27 years old.

He works in the sales of general merchandise such as clothing (tee shirts, pants, jeans, socks), tennis shoes, natural remedies, and sweet pastries prepared by his mother). He sells in different locations, riding around on his motorcycle. The route that he takes is in a large section of the 2nd Department of San Pedro.

Cesar also is the director of a musical group called “Los Madrigales del Ritmo” with 7 members, performing in many locations in the 2nd Department.

His dream is to have more musical instruments that he currently lacks in order to put on a better show in each concert that he does. For this reason, he is requesting this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase musical instruments

loans.name: Sofia

texts.es:
Sofia es socia del Banco Comunal Villa Huatatas.
Sofia es casada, tiene 35 años y 2 hijos, Sofia junto a su esposo tiene carros con los cuales realiza transporte de pasajeros, Sofia se encarga de la administración.
Sofia necesita un préstamo de 900 soles dinero que será invertido en el mantenimiento de su carro.
Los sueños de Sofia son que sus hijos sean profesionales y salir adelante con su negocio.
texts.en:
Sofia is a member of the communal bank "Villa Huatatas." Sofia is married, 35 years old, and has two children. She lives with her husband, who has cars that he uses to provide public passenger transportation services. Sofia is in charge of managing the business. Sofia needs a loan of 900 Peruvian soles that she will invest in the maintenance of her car. Sofia dreams of having her children become professionals and succeeding with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: for car maintenance

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
Julio Cesar forma parte del banco comunal “LOS DIAMANTES”, tiene 43 años, es natural de la ciudad de Anta, es conviviente y tiene tres hijos. Su actividad económica principal es brindar servicios de seguridad personal de forma particular. Actualmente, el socio trabaja en el Ministerio del Interior como personal de confianza de un funcionario público. Ya son 8 años que se dedica a brindar el servicio y le ha va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Su actividad económica complementaria es  crianza, comprar y venta de animales menores como por ejemplo cuyes, el tiene un galpón en su casa donde actualmente tiene 40 cuyes hembras. 

Julio Cesar es una persona trabajadora y emprendedora que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos, el requiere el préstamo para ampliar el galpón y comprar cuyes de raza. El socio con cuenta mucha tristeza que la humedad afecto a sus cuyes muriéndose una considerable cantidad pero el socio apesar de las adversidades del clima seguirá con el negocio. 

El anhelo del socio es ampliar el negocio comprando en cantidades cuyes para vender en las festividades importantes como por ejemplo en el aniversario de la ciudad del Cusco y tambien su deseo es abrir un restaurante donde va vender platos tipos de la región como por ejemplo el “Chiriuchu”. El banco comunal tiene 10 ciclos de funcionamiento, el socio manifiesta, que se encuentra contento y satisfecho con los servicios de crédito, ahorro y capacitación, por el tiempo de permanencia en el banco comunal. 
           
El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Julio Cesar is part of the communal bank 'Los Diamantes'. He is 43 years old and is from the city of Anta. He lives with his partner and 3 children. His principal economic activity is providing personal security. He works for the Ministry of the Interior as a trusted personal assistant to a public functionary. He has been doing this for 8 years and has done very well, thanks to the effort he puts into his work. He also has a complementary economic activity - breeding, buying and selling small animals such as guinea pigs. Julio has a small shed at his house where he has 40 female guinea pigs. Julio Cesar is a very hard-working and empresarial person who is always looking for ways to move forward. By working hard each day he wants to give his children a better future. He requires a loan to expand his shed and purchase a breed of guinea pigs. Julio tells us with great sadness that the humidity has affected his guinea pigs, and a considerable quantity have died. Notwithstanding the adversities of the climate, he will continue with the business. Julio's yearning is to expand his business, buying guinea pigs in quantity to sells them during important festivals, such as the city of Cusco's anniversary. He would also like to open a restaurant selling typical food from the region, such as 'Chiriuchu'. The communal bank has been functioning for 10 loan cycles and Julio stats that he is content and satisfied with the credit services, savings and capacity, for the time that the bank has existed. Julio is very thankful for the opportunity granted to him and promises to meet the payments according to the schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand shed and purchase guinea pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy and stock kola nuts

loans.name: Paulina

texts.es:
Paulina es socia del Banco Comunal Villa Huatatas.
Paulina es viuda, tiene 48 años y 6 hijos, Paulina viaja a las diferentes ferias D. la región en donD. compra cereales, papa, productos que venD. en el mercado D. abastos D. la ciudad.
Paulina necesita un préstamo D. 900 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. papa.
Los sueños D. Paulina son salir adelante y brindar buena educación a sus nietos.
texts.en:
Paulina is a member of the communal bank Villa Huatatas. Paulina is 48 years old and is a widow. She has 6 children. Paulina travels to different markets in the region where she buys cereals, potatoes, and other products, which she sells in the grocery market in the city. Paulina needs a loan of 900 soles to invest in the purchase of potatoes. Her dreams are to move forward and give her grandchildren a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase potatoes

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria es socia del Banco Comunal Villa Huatatas.
Victoria es viuda, tiene 50 años y 6 hijos, Victoria se dedica al procesamiento D. cereales, productos que compra del mercado, luego lo tuesta y lo manda a moler en molino alquilado, sus ventas los realiza en la ciudad D. Cañete.
Victoria necesita un préstamo D. 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. cereales.
Los sueños D. Victoria son que sus hijos sean profesionales y mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Victoria is a member of the communal bank Villa Huatatas. She is 50 years old and is a widow with 6 children. Victoria works processing cereals, which she purchases in the market. She roasts them and sends them to be ground in a mill, selling the final product in the city of Cañete. Victoria requires a loan of 1500 soles to invest in the purchase of cereals. Her dreams are that her children become professionals and that she improves her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cereals

loans.name: Put Together Group

texts.en:
Put Together is a group of five borrowers, headed by Ruth D.. She is 52 years old and did not go to school due to lack of financial support. She is widowed and has four children whose ages range from 30 to 20 years old. Some of her children are high school graduates and the rest are in high school. She also helps to care for two siblings.

Mary sells dried fish and palm oil. She buys in bulk and sells at retail, and she has been doing this business for 19 years. She started her business with the help of her late husband. Her challenge is limited business capital to get more fish and oil for resale. Her business is located on 12th Street in Sinkor. 

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Ruth is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/team/team_leap_liberia

loans.use: To get more fish and oil for resale

loans.name: Maria Karina

texts.es:
La señora es de la ciudad de Guayaybi Calle 2000 Def. Del Chaco, es casada, con 3 hijos, su esposo es encargado de una Estación de servicios.
La señora es propietaria de la MINISHOP(venta de bebidas y comestibles) ,se dedica a la ventas de bebidas,golosinas,comidas rápidas en general, servicio de Maxi y Mini carga para teléfonos celulares,  ventas de tarjeta para teléfonos celulares, la señora comenzó con un pequeño negocio ahora gracias gracias a su esfuerzo y dedicación  ha ampliado bastante  su negocio. 
Actualmente ya cuenta con gran cantidad de mercaderías.
Su sueño es tener un salón comercial para poder brindar un buen servicios a sus clientes, solicita el crédito para comenzar ha construir el salón comercial.
Es una señora honesta trabajadora y responsable esta muy agradecida por la ayuda y el buen servicios que le brinda la entidad.
texts.en:
This woman is from the city of Guayaybi, Street 2000, Def. Del Chaco. She is married and has three children. Her husband is in charge of a service station. She owns a Mini-shop (where she sells drinks and food). She sells drinks, sweets, general fast foods, Maxi and Mini chargers for cell phones, and cards for cell phones. She started with a small business, and now, thanks to her effort and dedication, her business has expanded quite a bit. She currently has a great quantity of merchandise. Her dream is to have a commercial salon to be able to offer good services to her customers. She is requesting the loan to start building the commercial salon. She is a hard-working and responsible woman. She is very grateful for the help and the good services given by this entity

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bricks

loans.name: Gabiro Group

texts.fr:
Jeanine Habinomana est une commercante agee de 30 ans qui habite la commune de Rugombo (en province de Cibitoke) dans l'ouest de Burundi.  Elle a fait ses etudes jusqu'en troisieme primaire.  Son mari est cultivateur.  Elle vend des habits au marche central de Rugumbo.  Auparavant, elle exercait le metier de cultivateur en plus de son commerce de vendre des habits, mais depuis un an elle s'est engage totalement dans le commerce.

Elle est mere de deux enfants; une fillette de 4 ans et un garcon de 18 mois.  Elle lutte pour que ses enfants puissent etudier et terminer avec succes afin qu'ils vivent aisement.

Elle demande le credit Turame-Kiva pour augmenter les quantites des habits qu'elle vend aux clients.  Elle espere pouvoir surmonter divers problemes de la vie, mais aussi lutter contre la pauvrete, grace aux revenus tires de ce commerce.  Elle encourage des autres a demander le credit Turame-Kiva parce qu'elle a vu comment cela lui a permis de surmonter certains problemes dans son menage.  Elle est une des membres du groupe "Gabiro" et est au deuxieme cycle de credit.
texts.en:
Jeanine Habinomana, 30, is a businesswoman who lives in the township of Rugombo (in the province of Cibitoke) in the west of Burundi. She attended school up to grade 3. Her husband is a farmer. She sells clothing in the central market of Rugumbo. Earlier, she used to work as a farmer besides selling clothing, but for the past year, she has been devoting herself completely to her business. She is the mother of two children, a little girl of 4 and a boy of 18 months. She is doing everything she can to guarantee that her children will be able to go to school and finish their studies so that they can live comfortably. Jeanine is requesting the loan from Turame-Kiva to add to her inventory of clothing that she sells her customers. She hopes to be able to surmount life's various difficulties, and also to struggle against poverty, thanks to the income from her business. She encourages others to request a Turame-Kiva loan because she has seen how much it has helped her to deal with household problems. She is a member of the 'Gabiro' group and is on her second loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying clothing for resale

loans.name: Lawenignina

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur est un informaticien de formation, il a ouvert une boutique de vente en détail de matériel informatique qu’il a appelé « PROTON ELECTRONIQUE », il fait ce commerce depuis 2003 et s’approvisionne à Lomé. Voulant augmenter son stock, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de divers consommables informatiques et assurer le transport des marchandises.
Il est marié et père de 3 enfants.
texts.en:
This gentleman is a trained computer specialist, who opened a retail shop for computer–related equipment he named “Proton Electronique”. He has been running this business since 2003 and gets his supplies in Lomé. Wanting to increase his stock supply, he is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy various computer consumables and ensure transportation of the merchandise. He is married and the father of three children.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy computer consumables

loans.name: Yesica Alsira

texts.es:
Yesica E. de 25 años, vive en una zona periurbana en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento esta ubicada a lado de un mercado de comidas y cuenta con todos los servicios básicos en su vivienda. Es madre soltera tiene una hija de 6 años que estudia en una escuela particular. 

Desde que Yesica era pequeña su mama tenía una tienda de víveres y ella le ayudaba a vender los productos de la tienda pero cuando creció y salio embarazada necesitaba un ingreso para su hija y decidió invertir sus ahorros en víveres y tener una tienda como su mama. 

En la actualidad tiene 8 años ya con la tienda trabaja desde las 05:30 am hasta las 23h30 pm, en ocasiones su mama le ayuda en la tienda para ella poder atender a su hija. Con el préstamo quiere comprar arroz, azúcar y aceite para su negocio.

En el futuro quiere arreglar mejor su casa especialmente el techo que esta muy deteriorado.
texts.en:
Yesica E. is 25 years old, and lives in the outskirts of Guayaquil. Her house is made of cement, and located next to a food market. She has all the basic necessities in her house. She is a single mother of a 6-year old daughter who is in school. Since Yesica was small, her mother had a general store where she helped out selling the various products they carried. When she grew up and became pregnant, she needed income for her child and decided to invest her savings into starting a store like her mother’s. Currently, she has had the store for 8 years, working from 5:30 am until 11:30 pm. In some instances, her mother helps her tend to the store so she can care for her daughter. With this loan, she would like to buy rice, sugar and oil for her business. Her future plans include making some repairs to her home, particularly to her roof, which is in poor condition.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar and oil.

loans.name: Ayao

texts.fr: Ce monsieur exerce comme activité la vente en détail de CD, il a commencé ce commerce en 2008 et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé, il n’a jamais obtenu du crédit de WAGES, il sollicite son premier crédit afin d’acheter 80 CD  audios et 150 CD vidéos. Il est mariée et père de trois enfants.
texts.en:
This gentleman’s commercial activity is the retail sales of CDs. He started this line of business in 2008 and gets his supplies from the main market in Lomé.
